reviewText: Hello, my old friend.\n\nYears ago, I remember walking into a local Wal-Mart to browse through the bargain bin of Psx games. reviewText:
Having completed the Steam version and PS1 version back to back, here are a few things I noted:

- The button layout can be confusing in certain sequences if using a controller, for example; telling you to press B2 or B5 as instructed, requiring you to remember your controllers personal button layout.
- All polygons look much better in this version, obviously, but it often clashes very unnaturally with the low res backdrops.
- A lot of the ported-to-midi music is noticably worse than the original, some peices sounding broken and off key
- Character portraits look a lot nicer and more detailed in Steam version.
- The gameplay seems to have been sped up by about 25%, which makes the frame rate APPEAR smoother, although animations still seem to be quite choppy. Particularly makes battles and traversing the world map seem much smoother!
- Various scenes will load much faster, ie; card battles and the startup screen, which is a big quality of life difference!
- 360 degree movement doesn't work by default, only 8 direction. I'm not sure if this can be modded.

When all is said and done, I personally prefer the original PS1 version, but if you don't have access to it, this version is not a bad option either. Hope this was helpful. :)

reviewText: The black sheep of the Final Fantasy series, Final Fantasy VIII is a game that divides opinion to this very day. Is it good? Is it bad? Does it make a lick of sense? Is Squall a sexy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? No one entirely agrees on an answer to any of these questions (except for the last one, the answer of which is YES), but I have my own take it. FFVIII is perhaps the most underappreciated games in the entire series. Much like how FFVII deconstructed JRPGs that existed up to that point, FFVIII deconstructs the wave of RPGs that followed in Final Fantasy VII's wake, mocking their tropes and characters, while at the same time telling a very unique story. FFVIII follows Squall Leonheart, a student at Balamb Garden, a military academy that trains SeeDs, a mercenary force designed for one purpose: to hunt down and destroy Sorcerresses. Squall is probably my favorite lead character in a Final Fantasy game, and that has one clear reason: he's realistic. Unlike Cloud or Zidane, he isn't a teenager who can somehow fight the forces of darkness without sweat: he's a flawed person, broken by a crappy childhood and a dehumanising education that taught him how to kill. In essence, he behaves how a real person would in his situation. Over the course of the game, we're treated to a near-constant internal monologue that tells us about the struggles he faces internally and how he deals with them. He's a great lead. The rest of the cast is more mixed, with high points being Irvine, who often reflects Squall, and Laguna, who's chipper attitude is a nice respite from the grim tones of Squall, and low points being the annoying and fairly useless Zell, the bland and boring Quistis, and the game's dumb villain, Ultimecia. The plot itself is also a bit of a mixed bag, with some really good moments offset by some really dumb ones. The battle system is a clear departure from the rest of the series too. Rather than levelling up your characters to build stats, instead, stats are built by junctioning" magic to various stats to increase their parameters. This is a great system
recommended: hampered by one thing: Drawing. Magic works like items in FF8: once you use a charge
hoursPlayed: it's gone. The only way to get magic early on is by painstakingly drawing magic from enemies: an incredibly tedious and boring prospect. It's rectified later once you get access to card refinement
voteText: but it's still a hassle. Speaking of card refinement. this game comes with a very entertaining trading card diversion called Triple Triad
helpfulPercent: and it's a blast. Simple
votesHelpful: quick
votesTotal: yet endlessly addictive.\n\nSo
votesFunny: that's Final Fantasy VIII. Honestly
commentsCount: I love it
column16: and it remains one of my favorites of the series. However

column18: so chances are

column20: approach it with an open mind
column21: and I think you'll enjoy what lies in store."

reviewText:
If you've never played a Final Fantasy game in your life, then here's a great place to start.

The Final Fantasy games have suffered from their ups and downs over the years, and VIII is no exception. If you take the time to search for opinions on the internet, you'll find a myriad of opinions ranging from one extreme to the other.

At it's heart though, I've found the game enjoyable, replayable - and the few aspects I do not like are swept under the rug.

As with most FF games, it relies on turn-based combat, but don't let that fool you. It is possible (and quite easy when you get the hang of it) to finish the game without levelling any of your characters at all. There are side quests aplenty, including the Triple Triad card game, which is fun for the most part, and the chocobo forest mini game.

The story is quite in-depth, so while I don't recommend it for the very young, based on this, it is still age and gender friendly - there is romance, comedy, plot twists, and a story and world so rich you might just not want to leave it.

The art style might take some getting used to, but the menu, and how magic and summons integrate with characters, may be the biggest hurdle for new players. Simply put - I didn't use magic. Summons are junctioned" to characters to grant them abilities
date: not the least of which is the ability to link collected magicks to your stats

reviewText:
TL;DR?: Don't buy, yet, wait for a sound mod or SE patch.

I picked up this game quite eagerly after missing out on FF8 on the PS1. Sadly I was incredibly dissapointed in the poor job Square Enix had done in porting the game to Steam.

First problem, I had to navigate a menu that after refusing my Facebook account, forced me to sign up to Square Enix's website. A pain, but a minor one I would have forgotten.

Second problem, which damns the game and makes it unplayable, the sound. This appears petty, but the lack of the PS1 soundtrack, one of the games defining features, is lost with the MIDI versions which seriously takes away from the games atmosphere. This is especially damning when you consider how dated the games graphics are, which whilst not a problem on its own, the poor sound artifically ages the game and damages the experience. FF7 received a number of Mods and even an offical patch to fix the sound problem alone, I'd say its worth holding out for one of these until you buy.

It is a shame really, as the core gameplay is fantastic, the depth of the RPG mechanics still intact and there is a lot to pick apart in the story, though the lack of a good soundtrack (Which hopefully will be improved in the coming weeks) really does lessen the quality of the package. Hold off buying this until Square Enix or some modder updates the soundtrack, at which point I would actually recommend picking this up.

reviewText:
Thinking all the time, never saying a word. Looking miserable, wearing awful black clothes. Being rude to people, mood swings.

Remember when you where a teenager? Perhaps you are one, and that is why Final Fantasy VIII is a hidden gem, concealed by the fact, hype and fans of 7 & 9.

Final Fantasy VIII is in many ways like other FF's, its set in a huge explorable world upon which, a situation arises, threatening its existence, companions are gathered along the journey to prevent it. But what 8 has done is extraordinary although it has to be said, unappreciated. This fantasy is through the eyes of a teenager, Squall, dubbed a Leonardo Dicaprio look-alike misery guts. Which is without doubt true, and possibly a strong reason why so many detest this game, living-reliving the life of a teenager in a world that is the closest to this one than any other FF game beyond 7. Effectively taken place in a Garden (school/college) where the students are trained to be become functioning members of an elite group of soldiers known as SEED. Ok not exactly a clever or exciting plot at first glance but this is only the beginning of something overlooked. Everything about it has that youthful learning element to it, such as the SEED tests as a means of gaining regular income, testing your knowledge of enemies, magic and general surroundings, you participate in field exams where you are graded accordingly on time, battles, attitude, spirit etc. oh and you're not aloud to buy a porn mag because you're to young.

Like all successful square games, it begins slow but picks up the pace by new events, addictive mini games and tugs on your heart strings with a puppy love storyline. Clearly, gamers have taken one look at the indifferent main character they must control and shake their fist in disgust that they aren't a mysterious mercenary, fun loving optimist athlete or a womanizing thief with a tail. I'll admit there are moments in the dialogue where you get annoyed at the ignorance of said character, such phrases like go talk to a wall" are aimed at someone spilling their emotional guts and "whatever" occurs repeatedly followed by "....." making Squall an essentially unresponsive cold jerk.. what he wants you to think.. however the time I played this

reviewText: I am a huge Final Fantasy fan so a re-release of one of my childhood favourites was a must-have for me. This is an absolutely fantastic game with such a gripping story. Okay, it doesn't have the graphics that modern games do but they have certainly done a pretty decent job at improving what already existed to make it look pretty good. The only downside to this steam addition is the soundtrack being in MIDI, but that is easily fixed with the Roses & Wine mod. You can even have custom game music and load up The Black Mages for battles if you so wish. If you've never played a Final Fantasy game, I would certainly recommend this one to wet your taste buds. It has everything a good RPG should have; a turn based battle system, gripping story and characters you get emotionally attached to (well, except Selphie in my opinion but I accept that some people do like her). If you don't already own this game, you need to buy it right this second.

reviewText:
For many of us, we seek to relive the nostalgia that FF8 would offer to us through steam. This review will be a juxtaposition of the PS1 version and the Steam version.

I guess I'll start with a few pros:

+You can simultaneously play Chocobo World while playing FF8. Chocobo World was not offered on the console version of FF8, so I thought this was a nice addition to the game.
+There are much faster loading screens. I think this was one of the most notable things seeing as how I would spend 50% of my time on the console version just staring at a black loading screen between transitions.
+Cloud Saving - No, not referring to FF7, but this is a nice way to save your progress without having to deal with memory cards. You will always have your non-corrupt Squall wherever you go.

Now, for some cons:

-MIDI files are messed up. If you're a big FF fan, you will know that the music plays a big role in the series. The fact that the MIDI files sound like garbage just tells us that Square Enix did not give a **** about the PC port. Thankfully, there is a mod/fix for this, so it's not that big of a deal.
-If the Square Enix servers are down, then you're not able to play your offline single player game. I'm not sure if this is primarily because of the cloud server, but it's annoying.
-You need a Square Enix account to play. This can be problematic because.. well, a lot of people experience all sorts of problems. Some have problems navigating the site, while others are still waiting for their email confirmation.
-This is the PC version, but that doesn't mean that the keyboard controls will be great. If you want to fully enjoy the PC experience, I would recommend a controller for your PC. I bought one for about 20$.

I actually did not swap out the music, did not have (too) many problems with accessing my account and still managed to almost get 200 hours into the game.

All in all, despite a handful of annoying flaws, I like the PC port. Am I adamant on strongly recommending this game? No. In fact, I would ONLY recommend buying this if you have played a previous version of FF8 and/or if it's on sale.

If you are new to the Final Fantasy series, I would not recommend this as you will probably be dismayed by the frustrating flaws of the steam version. This could potentially just leave a bad taste on your tongue overall for FF8, too.

TL;DR - Buy if you're a veteran and/or if it's on sale; skip if you're new to the game.

reviewText:
Originally released on the Playstation and then ported to the PC, the Steam copy of Final Fantasy VIII is a fairly cheap way to access one of the PS1 era classics while also getting to use the Pocket Station game Chocobo World (a mini-game that didn't come included with non-PS1 versions of Final Fantasy VIII outside of Japan, which can give items in FFVIII.)

I'll get right to the negatives, not just of this port, but of Final Fantasy VIII.

[ CONS ]
These are pure problems.

-MIDI music. There's guides on Steam for how to fix this, but the fact remains a fresh install will see lower quality music in various situations than in the PS1 version.

-Square Enix DRM on the launcher. If their servers go down for maintenance, you can't play your single player game. That's stupid.

-If you already have Final Fantasy VIII, Chocobo World's really going to be your only major draw to this, since cloud saves don't justify the above DRM.

-Final Fantasy VIII's story requires a lot of work on you, the player's part to make it decent. This seems to stem from odd narrative choices and mistranslations, but the fact remains you might find yourself disappointed with a world where child soldiers are led by Evil Robin Williams to battle a Double Witch. YMMV.

-Gamepad support is iffy. Sometimes, if your gamepad disconnects for any reason, even if you reconnect it, you're stuck using the keyboard until you close out and re-open the game.

[ MIXED ]
Middle of the road.

+/-The magic system in this game is polarizing. Essentially, you use a command called Draw to take some magic from what you're fighting. Then you can equip that magic onto your stats via a feature called Junctioning. You can also get this magic from other sources, like converting items (cards come to mind). I personally don't get the hate for it, the system's pretty simple and lets you inch out whatever level scaled opponents you're facing with minimal thought involved, but note a lot of people don't like it.

+/-With the relatively young age of the main protagonists, the ... Gunblades, and the odd direction the story tends to go in - while there's a unique identity to the world of this game, it can feel like a high school drama with magic and gun swords thrown into it sometimes.

+/-It has a better story than Final Fantasy XIII. But that's not saying much.

+/-Hard to relate with the romance build up between Squall and Rinoa (two main characters), but I'm sure there's fans for that.

[ PROS ]
Where the game does well.

+If you don't have Final Fantasy VIII and are a Steam addict, it takes three seconds to fix that Midi issue above. Square Enix sales happen a lot too, so the game's usually dirt cheap.

+Triple Triad. When the world is on the brink of destruction, play card games.

+You can cheat. Cheat a lot. Use the launcher to give yourself a ton of drawn magic, or use the hidden Function Keys to cheat in all kinds of things. While no Final Fantasy game is hard, this can be very useful for speed running or getting yourself up to a certain point in the game if desired.

+Lots of Steam community material on where and how to mod Final Fantasy VIII into a better looking, better playing game is available.

+Final Fantasy music. Always good.

+Guardian Forces (this game's summons) actually level up and unlock you new abilities. This and the square button mashing damage bump when you summon them in battle makes them a lot more interesting than Final Fantasy VII's cutscene spam.

+Everything concerning Chocobos, be it the Tamagotchi style Chocobo World or the overworld chocobo mining, is enjoyable.

+You serve under Robin Williams, Evil Headmaster Military King who trains children to use experimental demon magic, casually hands students he wants to see die lamps that transport them to hell to fight Satan without telling them what it does. It is implied he banged the main antagonist while possessing a minor protagonist, so he was in bed with a Triple Witch. Furthermore, when the actual owner of the Garden (think flying military base) gets mad that he tried to have a political leader -murdered and fails during an already tenuous war- and attempts to placate said understandably angry nation, Headmaster Robin Williams has the appropriate response in mind after stomping off from the well mannered NORG, his lips profusely wet from screaming.

CHILDREN? FIGHT TO THE DEATH"

Did I mention there's a dating hangout area for the students of this Garden
date: and so he has Tyrannosaurus Rex(multiple) stocked there for "training purposes?"\n\nThe guy's a menace. Play this game so you can discover how Robin Williams nearly doomed the world."

reviewText:
By far the Playstation version is better than the Steam version:

[PROS]
-Steam achievements
-Smoothed graphics or original Playstation 1 graphic settings available
-Great soundtrack*
-Attacking can be hands-on (Example: using Squall’s gunblade or Zell’s Limit Break)
-Magic Booster available via the launch menu
-Cheats are available via the Function keys
-Cheats do not affect Steam achievements
-Tons of creative monster/landscape designs
-Triple Triad card game
-Chocobo World included

[CONS]
-In order to play Final Fantasy VIII an account must be created with Square Enix
-Save files CAN BE LOST due to the Steam's cloud syncing, so be sure to turn off cloud syncing before playing (Library>Games>Right click on Final Fantasy VIII>Properties>Update>Uncheck 'Enable Steam Cloud Synchronization for Final Fantasy VIII')
-*Great soundtrack but… the sound is awful on the Steam version due to MIDI; however, this can be fixed (http://steamcommunity.com/app/39150/discussions/0/666828126495993258/#c666828126498515672)
-Guardian Force (GF) summoning time can be too long such as for Eden
-If you’re hardcore into grammar the typos (mostly in the beginning of the game) may drive you insane
-Rinoa.  (She has always driven me insane since the first time I played this game, and the few times where you have to save her in the game I never wanted to save her)

Then there's the PocketStation game Chocobo World available via the launch menu to Final Fantasy VIII.  This mini-game can be muted via your computer's sound settings (Windows 7>Speaker/Volume Control>Mixer) and run in the background taking care of itself.  Personally, I find Chocobo World boring; however, Boko the Chicobo can find items (ranked A through D), which can be useful to your saved game once you finish your first Chocobo Forest (Final Fantasy VIII 'Disc 2').  Also, leveling up Boko to certain levels and meeting certain event requirements in Chocobo World can allow Boko to use powerful attacks in FF8's main story with Gysahl Green.

Keep in mind that the Steam version of Final Fantasy VIII is far from a remake; therefore, the graphics, sound, and game play are still on par with the Playstation version released in 1999.

reviewText:
This is a very mixed bag.   First of all I recommend purchasing this release purely for the fact it is available legally, and will run without any major issues,  no hacks/mods/patches etc needed.

However,  I feel like the quality of this release is sub-par, compared even to the FF7 release.   FF8 was made for the PC -after- the technical failure that was the Final Fantasy VII PC version.  One of its features was higher resolution Full Motion Videos, and it did indeed deliver on this.   But I don't ever remember them looking as bad as they do in this release.   Whereas the  FF7 videos scaled up to 720p surprisingly well for their age.    Also some videos have very clearly show deinterlacing artifacts, which is puzzling  for something that should have been progressive from the start.      Not only did they do some kind of deinterlacing on some (or all?) parts of some videos,  but they did a ♥♥♥♥ poor job, using cheap blend deinterlacing which can clearly be seen in some scenes.

I was secondly unimpressed with the background art.   Now we know in FF7,  they were rendered in low-res and the artwork was lost or unavailable to render again at that that point in time;   did they truly make the same mistake again with FF8?    I don't have the original PC version to compare with, so I don't know.   But  some of the background art arguably looks worse than even FF7 did in some areas.   At best it looks about the same;  a pixelated mess.

The most offensive act however, is one again, the MUSIC.   Square got blasted for the crappy MIDI renders they released with FF7 both originally,  and then again just recently.   They had the audacity to include the audio in OGG format;  audio of  rendered MIDI.   The finally got a clue and just recently patched the REAL  Playstation Soundtrack back into the game.

So why the hell did they not do the same for FF8?   OK it clearly appears to use a slightly more non-standard  format for its MIDI music (and that's what it is.... General MIDI) but could they seriously  NOT  patch in the  OGG support like they did for FF7?   Could they not have applied fan-made  PSF hacks and included the original Playstation Music Files  and instrument samples?

That is just a glaring slap in the face.   But I suppose we should be grateful that they released it on Steam from the start this time,  instead of lying to customers  that it would only ever be in the Square-Enix store, like they did with FF7.....

One other minor annoyances is they appears to have changed the Overture.   The sequence of images is not only ugly and grainy (like the original PC release) but they appear to have changed the sequence and omitted one or two images, throwing off the timing,  so you are sitting at the white FF8 Logo/Title  while the Overture actually finishes.

reviewText:
FF8 is quite possibly the most discussed FF due to how the public percieves its story and what it really means.

I'll explain this game a little for players who missed this gem from back in the day. It is quite confusing to someone who's never played it before for the first time.

The game uses a GF system (Guardian Force = aka Infinite Use Summons in Battle with outside of battle skills)
Now you need GF's equipped on a character to use basic actions like using Summons, Drawing Magic from Monsters or using items.

It's important to realize that there is NO MP at all in this game. Think of Magic like Items. Only way to gain magic is from draw points on the world or Draw it from Monsters in combat.

With Magic you can Junction it onto your characters to give them a boost in Stats to greatly increase their capabilities, like putting Fire on STR to boost Damage, or stack Cure onto HP to give your characters a boost in Max Health.

The more of a certain Magic you have while Junctioned onto a stat, the greater the bonus. So you'll get more STR bonuses from 100x Fire rather than just having 15x Fire. The same goes for the Level of Magic too. So you'll get even more bonuses to stats for Junctioning Higher Level Magic onto your Stats rather than Low Magics. (Like Cure vs Curage. Curaga gives much more to bonuses)

Now everyone should take note that the Limit Breaks in this game are different. You don't get a limit Meter. As such it can be abused to hell if you really want it to, just leave your characters in Low (Yellow) HP and watch your Limit Breaks wreck everything for you, making the game considerably easier.

This is a game EVERY JRPG player should experience once in their life. The music is top tier. Boss battles are blood pumping with the music, the story is pretty good and the Superbosses are really fun. Not to mention Squalls and Irving's limit breaks at endgame can completely wreck any boss in a matter of seconds.

To sum it all up. This is by far my favourite Final Fantasy, besides Tactics of course.

GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT, GET IT!

reviewText:
This is a bad version of this game, and it's a travesty that Square is charging 11 dollars for this. Seriously, just play the PS1 version if you really need to play FF8 again.

The music in this version is PC MIDI, which causes the entire OST to sound off in comparison to the original. Square said that they would update this version with the original OST, but they never did. There are music mods, but I couldn't get most of them to work, and the one I did get to work didn't even have the songs set to properly loop. Amazing.

On top of that, this version has very jittery looking eight way digital movement that feels terrible, while the PS1 version had analog support. There are also some issues, especially with sound effects, that aren't present in the original PS1 version.

The only benefits from this version are the higher resolution UI, FMVs, and better quality models, but that's about it. I guess achievements too, if that's your thing.

Keep in mind that this version also adds optional microtransactions for whatever reason. Just avoid it, do yourself a favor, and emulate the PS1 version on ePSXe.  Don't waste 11 bucks.

reviewText:
You need a Square Enix account to play, which may be problematic because the Square website is a bit fussy with their confirmation emails. I got mine about 24 hours after I asked for it. Playing with achievements is nice, and this is the only way I've found where you can access Chocobo World, but the music is low-quality MIDIs for some reason, and you need to download a mod to restore the audio.

If you're an old fan looking to come back, I'd just see if I could find a PS1 and a disc instead. Newcomers, maybe give it a shot, but be prepared to wait for that email.

EDIT: Also crashes like a blind Nascar driver. You know those sections with the ticking timer that gives you game over if they hit zero? Imagine one of those ALWAYS counting down and you can't see it. That's what it's sort of like playing this. A crash ever seems to be lurking around the corner. It makes you paranoid and tense, and it's not the least bit fun.

Do yourself a favor and track down a PS1 disc and a system to play on. Do not waste your money on this.

reviewText:
Despite my love for Final Fantasy, the PC releases for the series were never that great. While Final Fantasy VII was salvaged by having a fairly simple implementation on the Playstation One, Final Fantasy VIII has a significant problem when compared to it's alternate platform.

Let's put it simply, the PC version of Final Fantasy VIII was terrible. It looks terrible, it sounds terrible. Music shipped with this release is an unexcusably terrible cacophany of MIDI instruments that lack in detail that made the Playstation One release as great as it was. Despite the potential for better hardware, the game looks fairly terrible when on the field and in certain 3D environments. Texture tiling is rampant in the overworld, whereas the Playstation One version managed to avoid that alltogether.

I love being able to play VIII on the PC, but it comes with the sheer bitter taste of knowing that what I'm seeing is nowhere near as good as it was on the first platform I played the game on. Even with it being as old as it is, it's a damned shame that the PC version of this game had it's artwork stripped bare of what made it look and sound so good.

That's not even getting into the playability part. With everything in the game being referenced as Button 1" through whatever

reviewText:
(no spoiler review) Final Fantasy VIII:  A pretty good RPG with some really interesting mechanics. It is now the highest number FF game I've beat, so you can tell I'm behind in the series. Even though I only just beat it, I actually owned and played FF VIII the year it came out, but got so addicted to Triple Triad that I never progressed the main story more than a few hours; so it felt really good to go back and finally beat it.

A lot of the game systems threw me off at first.  Understanding Junctioning and GFs took me a really long time to figure out. Once I got used to the system, I really liked it. It was addicting to level up by GFs to get new abilities and stats on them, especially when it meant I could open up a stat to junction magic onto, which made the characters much more powerful.

However, as the game progressed, the attaching gfs and abilities to each character became probably my biggest complaint about the game. The reason for this is that every friggin' 10 minutes your party either splits off, or certain characters become unavailable, or you switch between parties, and every single time you have to switch junctions, abilities and magic to your new group (and if it affects their hp then you have to waste cure magic to bring their hp up). This drove me crazy and really disrupted the flow of the game.

I highly enjoyed the Steam version of FFVIII. I read a bunch of complaints about the Steam version, but the only one that I thought was valid was that all the music was in midi format, which made it all sound horrible. Luckily, someone created a mod that replaced all the midi music files with non-midi ones, so once I installed that, I got all the regular music back again. Another bonus of the Steam version is that the game comes with a lot of cheats. They have some pretty heavy ones, like always have full health, or always do 9999 damage. The only cheat" I indulged in was the amazing high-speed mode. By pressing F1
date: you could activate high-speed mode which sped everything up by a factor of five. I found this to be a great QoL feature that I used mainly during the game's ridiculously long summon sequences
hoursPlayed: and parts that I had to repeat due to me dying and reloading a save. This feature
voteText: along with the Half-Encounter/No-Encounter abilities one of my GFs learned
helpfulPercent: made it so I could cut through overly long segments and random encounters if I didn't want to deal with them.\n\nAs for the story and characters

reviewText: I, personally, don't know why the bloody hell people dislike this game so much.  Sure, the junction system takes some getting used too (especially if you're used to the traditional MP system) and continually drawing magic from enemies can, and will get tedious, (have your GFs learn them refining abilities!)  not to mention the teen drama style story might not be up everyone's ally, but in all fairness, FF8 is a solid game with a ton of nostagia surrounding it, for me anyway.  The smooth looking Steam version is very appealing to the eyes, but the stock midi format music kind of kills the trip down memory lane for me. I mean come on! FF8 has, in my opinion, one of the best soundtracks in the Final Fantasy collection. I can understand making the game smaller in size, but the music is a key factor in the whole Final Fantasy experience.  (Nobuo Uematsu is a game music GENIUS!)  But fear not friends, get the Roses and Wine mod for oust the midis and replace them with the original PS1 music, or add some of the different songs that come included, I recomend the orchestrated Balamb Garden, Blue Fields, Boss music and Battle themes. The replacement Winhill flashback music is a good break from the original music box version too.  All in all, the Roses and Wine mod is a major saving grace for this purchase, and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
I'm mixed on this one. I would only recommend the steam version of this game if you're going to take the time to mod it in order to fix all the sound and graphics problems. However, if you're not willing to mod the steam version you might as well use an emulator or pull your old playstation out of the closet instead.

When I first installed and played the game I was highly dissapointed. The gorgeous music I remembered was replaced by horrible sounding midi and the textures are far more pixelated than I remember the game being. On top of that, I was having trouble getting my PS3 controller to work and had to play the game on keyboard, which I did not desire to do.

Upon searching for a controller fix I also found fixes for the graphics and music. After installing a set of mods (Tonberry w/ Seed Reborn, Project Eden, and Tripod) along with replacing the music files and getting the controller to work, my opinion on this game completely changed for the better and I am incredibly happy with my purchase. Yes, we shouldn't have to spend an hour modding a game we just purchased in order to make it pleasing to play, but this game is worth it. It is, and has always been, my favorite of the Final Fantasy series for it's story line, characters, environment design, music, and atmosphere.

reviewText:
Bad port of my favorite game ever.

This is my favorite game of all time. It's also a downgrade from the original version. The music is lower quality. To even start up the game is awkward. I also keep getting some notification in the top left corner during battle which has something to do with Steam and achievements. It's still a great game. But poor ports like this should be frowned upon. Oh and you also have to create a Square Enix account to even play this game.

Square is an awful company. Late 90s Square is the greatest company of all time; they put out the following games in a between 1997 and 2001:

Final Fantasy 7, Final Fantasy Tactics, Xenogears, Final Fantasy 8, Final Fantasy 9, and Final Fantasy X. Let me put it another way. In less than 5 years, old Square put out 6 of the greatest games ever made. I'm also not counting other fan favorites like Chrono Cross, Parasite Eve, and Vagrant Story. This company was a serious beast. After the release of FF12 (which was mediocre), it took the company 7 years to come out with FF13. FF13 is one of the worst games I've ever had the displeasure of playing.

New Square is garbage and only their Eidos brand puts out good products. Square itself develops trash and creates terrible ports of amazing games. How many version of FF4 are there now?

It's really hard for me to recommend this game. If you have no other way of playing this game, you should probably go ahead and buy it. Just know that it's not meant to be like this. I'm ashamed to even give this version a recommendation.

An aside -- don't purchase Square games on Steam. Not even great Square games. Square is just looking to churn out half-♥♥♥♥♥ ports to Steam users.

reviewText:
When I was a teen, placing in my PlayStation for the first time, I knew I would be a gamer for life.  This wasn't Sonic jumping on robot creatures or the pixelated curiosities that were the original Final Fantasy's on the NES.... This was a heartwarming journey weaving an epic and timeless tale of the human spirit.

I collect and play Final Fantasy games, and this one is my classic favorite.  The story and characters are more realistic than the previous games starting a trend in the series.  It hurts to relive the pixelated limits of 5th generating gaming, but if you can look past (as we all had to back then), you will see a beautiful 3D rendered world featuring elements from modern architecture, classic fantasy, sci fi, and steam punk.  This was one of the first multi-million dollar game productions, and it shows.  I'd love to see high-res versions of these backgrounds.

The magic draw system is tedious to play as a completionist, but it is a fun diversion for adventurers because with every enemy encounter, there is an opportunity to draw something unique you can use in gameplay.  Also, each of your party is setup like a blank slate and you strengthen them with magic you've drawn.  So, unlike other RPGs, you can create your own jobs using any of your favorite characters.  And the backgrounds, Enemies and GFs are artistically rendered, and it's easy to feel a sense belonging to this world.  For newcomers to classic RPGs, think of a large open world game like Skyrim or Fallout 3 with quests, but with a turn-based battle system.

Pro draw tips: Make every character able to draw and Mag-J if you can.  Find one weak enemy, draw with each character and hold down the confirm button.  I use Xpadder to toggle-hold it down.  If you have to draw from a stronger enemy, you can put one person on cure-duty, and I like to make Selphie weak on attack (no or weak Str-J and low level) and give her mug and put Stop on Status-J.  This is a good setup for the draw, and also a weak attack can help you bring their hp low without killing so you can finish them off by turning them into a card (which is refinable and also gains AP).  In the beginning of the game, I find galbadian soldiers (which have 4 spells) and Fish from Balamb are strong early draws.  When you convert a Fastitocalon fish to a card and refine it, you get 20 Water which is a midrange attack spell and a powerhouse on Str- J early in the game and defeating them yields 3 AP each which I think is even more lucrative for grinding than the famous cactaurs.

Also, there is a chance to play the game non-violently which should appeal to some including women and girls who may also appreciate the game's romantic undertones.  Most of the enimies are not evil minions.. They are more like nature's creatures in this fantasy world.  Gaining experience from killing is not really rewarded because the enimies gain xp as you do.  However, you can non-violently draw magic.  I have a combo team: One freezes the enemy and steals items with a weak whip attack, a second draws magic, and the third heals any damage recieved.  You can also gain the coveted AP (used for building abilities for the Guardian Forces which are like spirit-assistants in battle) by turning enimies into cards (which I like to imagine is like keeping them as a pet).

Not that this release isn't without problems.  To me, the most noticable omission is analog controls.  They were a great improvement over FF 7 and brought the more realistic characters to life.  Also, it's a shame the face lift didn't make the cards in the in-game card game, Tripple Triad, higher resolution.  I also didn't like the control customizations which don't support the triggers or the D-Pad on the X360 controller; although the extra buttons are really needed.  I used Xpadder to keyboard emulate to fix that and emulating the keyboard's confirm" key because the gamepad one doesn't work everywhere. Unfortunately
date: this means setting up both gamepad and kb controls in the game's settings.  I wish I could just disable gamepad support in the menu and do full keyboard emulation.  That way
recommended: I could keep it all in one place.\n\nIn fact

reviewText: Final Fantasy 8 is one of the more overlooked entries in the series. Talk to fans of the franchise and you will generally find that opinion is neatly divided on both gameplay elements and storyline. The easy to abuse Junctioning system and J-drama high-school esq plot will not appeal to everyone, but are worth experiencing if you are in anyway a fan of Final Fantasy or jrpgs. The music however is like having an entire casio keyboard ground up then forced roughly into your ear canal. Whilst the recent HD remake of Final Fantasy X had its score rearranged and brought up too our refined modern standards, with this game Square Enix seems to have taken the opposite approach and ‘de-made’ its soundtrack back to era before the original game was even created. The original PC release of FF8 featured the same MIDI chip tunes used here, possible to save space, however in 2014 I would expect the quality to be at least that of the console version from 15 years ago. Unfortunately I consider this to be a fatal issue. One of the key attractions of the Final Fantasy series has always been its music. It’s a core aspect of every game in the series and one which Square Enix’s marketing department defiantly recognises. So if you are going to go to the trouble of adding these extra features (the Japan only ‘Chocobo World’ mini-game is fully welcome) is it not worth polishing up one of the games major selling points whilst you are at it? It’s like putting sprinkles on a cupcake but not bothering to brush off the ants. In my mind the addition of an achievement system is not enough to outweigh ear wrenchingly poor music in any game, especially Final Fantasy. Unless you really really like achievements or have had your ears shaved off by a murderous barber, seek this game elsewhere.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy 8 is a black sheep in the franchise. It's got a really different battle system and a weird story.

Final Fantasy 8 does away with MP and replaces it with the Draw ability! This ability makes it so you have to 'draw' magic from your opponents or from specific areas in the world in order to use that magic. Magic is now treated like an item, you can only use as many 'fire' spells as you have stocked. In order to use magic (or any ability that isn't 'attack') you have to junction GFs. These GFs are the equivilant of Eidolons from the other Final Fantasy games and can be summoned during a fight. It can be a real pain to grind on enemies to obtain magic, but fortunately, the Steam version includes a 'magic booster' which gives you 100 of a few spells.

Now onto the story. Squall is... a strange character to say the least. If you thought Cloud Strife was dull, you're in for a surprise. Squall is silent, calculating, and has more internal dialogue then external. He has issues relying on people which becomes quite apparent throughout the game. The plot of the story is weird and confusing and has led to may theories on what actually happens during the game. The beginning is a lot more normal however. You are Squall Lionheart. You are a SeeD (pretty much a mercenary) in training and are about to perform in an exam to become fully ranked. You have a rival (kind of like pokemon) and you have a love interest later in the game. After the first disk, things that border the ridiculous start to happen, although they can be completely 100% explained.

I liked this game because the farther you got into the game, the more you found yourself enjoying it. This game has, in my opinion, one of the hardest final boss encounters in Final Fantasy. The ending's pretty dope too.

reviewText:
You would have thought after the FFVII debacle SquareEnix would make sure the latest Steam FF did NOT have the compressed, horrible MIDI music. Sadly this is not the case and once again you have to deal with ear diarrhea. Nevertheless, they did patch FFVII to have the high quality PSX music eventually so there is hope.

Apart from that, the port is as good as can be expected. Game runs smoothly and looks better than my PSX version slightly. There are some fun achievements if you're into that too, more interesting than FFVII's terrible ones at least.

The game itself is fun. Somewhat easy/game-breaking if you understand the Junction system but remains a game I usually beat every 1-2 years. Triple Triad is the highlight of the game, addictive, fun and a welcome distraction when the story begins to go off the rails slightly.

I recommend this (£10 is nothing for the time you'll get out of it).

reviewText:
General info
~Genre: Japanese roleplaying game (JRPG), belongs to Final Fantasy series
~Number of players: 1
~Completion time: 45-100 hours
~Partially enhanced (HD) version of already existing title

Strong points
+Story: A tale about the coming of age, the fear of loss, the acceptance of responsibilities, the need of expression, the importance of friendship and the warmth of love. Younger gamers might find the aforementioned topics quite boring, as I did back in the day, but as I grew up I understood why the developers chose to enrich their product with such thematology.

+Content: A game suitable for both young and mature audiences.

+Music: Don't take my word for it; just listen to the complete soundtrack
(uploaded on youtube by TantrisOST)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X6kAwpgW29M

+Tradition: Many well known figures and themes of the Final Fantasy universe make their appearance in Final Fantasy VIII: Prepare to fight Malboros and Tonberries, summon Shiva and Ifrit, cast Reflect and Ultima and ride chocobos. Also, many artists already involved in previous installments are back: Yusuke Naora, Kazushige Nojima, and composer Nobuo Uematsu.

+Team spirit: Create teams of three characters (from a total of six) and face challenging foes in a turn based battle-system. Experienced Final Fantasy players will tread on familiar ground while newcomers will adapt gradually thanks to the game's instructional early stages.

+Not another grinding fest: Final Fantasy VIII introduced the juctioning system with which you may team up with various summoning entities and enhance your stats, abilities and defences. Thus, instead of killing enemies for hours and hours in order to level up, you are able to apply various combinations of spells to enhance your characters. You can actually finish the game with your initial level (steam achievement) thanks to this innovative progress system.

+Road to the riches: You don't have to worry about buying your expensive equipment in FFVIII. Most items will be dropped from slained monsters or they can be crafted by collecting various ingredients with the help of your summoned creatures.

+Along came Behemoth: Enemies level up as you do. It's your choice where and when to increase your level of experience as well as how to fortify your team in order to overcome enemies who change attack pattern as your levels go up.

+Characters, NPCs, companions with interesting background and distinctive personalities. Most of them answer to the principles of japanese manga and anime culture; if you have played any other Final Fantasy game you know what to expect; and that's not necessarily a bad thing.

+Environment: Both urban and rural. You can visit cities, ports, schools as well as beaches, deserts and the infamous chocobo forests; by renting a car, riding a chocobo or exploring on foot!

+Chicobo: The famous pocketstation game Chocobo World which accompanied the original title is back! Train your little chocobo to the highest level, slain enemies and transfer all acquired loot to your main saved game in order to aid your team with powerful items.

+Rich background: Despite starting the game in medias res"
date: the complex background of the game will be revealead to players piece by piece as they progress. Visit the in-game Information section often to learn new things about the world you are exploring.\n\n+Controls: Customizable in-game settings
recommended:
controller support.

+For seasoned adventurers and newcomers: You can level your characters up to the maximum or stay at  a low level and depend on your juctions and individual skills only.

Weaknesses
-Problematic PC port: This port suffers from a few issues which can be fixed with various mods or community unofficial patches. The two major problems can be found on the sound and graphics department:     Despite the fact that characters
hoursPlayed: spells
voteText: summons and vehicles are graphically enhanced
helpfulPercent: the background remains in low resolution. Click  here for an example.\n\nAs for the sound
votesHelpful: the main issue is its bad quality. You can fix this problem by downloading a mod called Roses and Wine. Consult the Steam guide section  for links. SquareEnix could have spent more time improving their product.\n\n-Juctioning: Ironically
votesTotal: one of Final Fantasy VIII's best features is at the same time one of its flaws. Juctioning can make your team almost invincible and it's quite simple to comprehend as long as you have spent time on the tutorial understanding how the system works. Unfortunately
votesFunny: while the game extricates the players from many hours of useless killing

reviewText: Same old awesome game. No bugs and everything seems to work fine, though the graphics I wish would look a little less blurry/fuzzy when adjusted for my monitor. The only negative thing though that really stuck out I would say it's the music. I can stand this more because I actually first played this on the PC version, but the old MIDI music is a bit annoying (though I'm sure it was not easy to program). It becomes glaringly obvious during some of the more complicated pieces of music that represent shifts in the story, and it takes me away from the game more than I would like it to. I would guess though that they will get around to updating the music soon enough, since they did the same for ff7, so I will probably not play any more of this until then, as music is very important to me in the Final Fantasy series. I mean, the Final Fantasy series is essentially a melodrama plus an RPG, and in melodrama music is half of the entertainment.

reviewText: So, I randomly decided to buy this game for the nostalgic value. I hadn't played it for SO many years. It was one of the first games that piqued my interest in the RPG genre. I definitely didn't regret it.  Have been a fan ever since and the Final Fantasy series would still have to be my favourite, this game being number one. Totally recommend it to people who love a great story featuring so many different genres and elements. The characters, witty dialogue, as well as their development throughout the game are exceptional(Although Rinoa was slightly annoying this time round, all these years later). The slightly touched up character graphics featured in the PC version are really nice and far less pixelated. I found the battle system in this game to be rather unique and the game isn't very grindy. You can basically level as you please, most monsters/encounters level up with you. You can also turn random battles off after obtaining a specific GF (summon) and learning a certain skill .The card  mini-game known as Triple Triad would have to be one of my favourite aspects of the game also, it's a very fun and sometimes an extremely challenging mini game. Funnily enough after winning almost every card I still haven't become bored of it! Gotta win em all. >=o  The controls in the game are a little klunky, but nothing to really complain about.

reviewText:
One of the more under rated final fantasy games. Why is this you ask ? Mainly due to its draw and junction system.

Magic exsists in the title only by drawing from enemies useing the gf abilities such as life magic refine and or draw points scattered everywhere in the world. why dont people like this sytem? let me explain

Most people think you have to draw 100 of each magic to become extreamly powerful when that is not the case. you can infact refine powerful magic  from items early on in the game if you learn the right abilities. The junction system works like the equipment system. Basically you can junction magic to your base stat. Heres an exzample

Junction curaga >hp = 8000 base hp 1500  From that you should get the general idea  you can be at an extreamly low level (which is reccomended) and still beat the game. Monsters level up with you so lets say your strongest character is level 17 monsters will also be at level 17 including bosses. Some saymonsters level up with squall thats not the case.

There are items that increase your base stat with out leveling a lot of people that i know that play this game grind out those item so they have max hp as well as a 255 (max) base strength stat ect. I would not go that far its easier just to junction.

you do not gain gil in this game through battles instead you are given gil based on how many steps you take on a regular occurance. How much you get will be determained by your seed rank highest rank= a. I am not sure howmany steps it is but i am pretty sure it is based on that.

Triple triad ....
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B6pitTGz3tk

got that song in your head yet  ?  No  ?  Well you will. Playing cards in this game is almost a must. Each card in the game refines in to an item with the card mod ability. Some items you get can refine in to really good magic. Others refine into items you may need. If you played ff9 efore you played this then you should know how the card game works its fairly simalier and easy to learn. The only thing that sucks are the same and sameplus , random rules .

PRO TIP : Save your game before playing any card games. You do not want to loose your stronger cards such as gf and or character cards. you can win them back but its faster if you save and reset. This is where 50% of my time was put  :P  that and i am doing a playthrough on youtube

Shameless self promoting begings now ! Heres my latest video (as of this post) I try and update daily.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kkeTnK1Gebs

reviewText:
This is an excellent game of the franchise, frequently under stated and disliked by the Final Fantasy fanbase it lacks some of the plot of the predecessor FFVII but makes up for it with beuatiful video scenes and music tracks.

The conversion from the Playstation was well done but as with any game converted for PC after its creation there are a few flaws, none of which detract from the playability, most notably in the fluidity and layout. (Rather than completely redesign all interfaces the decision was made to alter the controls to a keyboard system simmilar to many emulators making some key combinations a bit challenging.) On the up side its entirely possible to hook a USB PS2 controller into your PC and use that instead of your keyboard and return to the original feel of the game.

Overall I would say its a great game, a great buy, and a great choice.

reviewText:
It's probably the most convenient way to play the game these days, and that counts for something. And it really is worth playing; it's the black sheep of the Playstation FF games, but that makes it interesting. It's broken, has an even more ridiculous plot than usual, dungeons are very often literally copy-pasted together, and the ever-present card game brings the pace to a crawl. But, it also has a great cast, interesting changes to the typical FF ruleset, the card game is fun, and the settings are varied and beautiful while creating a more consistent universe than its immediate predecessor.

THAT SAID...

If you have a Playstation/PS2 hooked up to a CRT TV/XRGB-type scaler, or an emulator with a good CRT TV simulation mode, you will have a vastly better experience. The game is designed around the limitations of the Playstation, and the PC version makes no attempt to hide the strings"

reviewText: The second Final Fantasy game to grace the Playstation console, Final Fantasy VIII had some big shoes to fill after the success of it's predecessor. Though considered by some to be a flop, I see FF VIII as one of the greatest stories in the series. With very well developed characters and hours of cut scenes, FF VIII delivers an epic and emotional ride. While the magic and combat system is a little quirky and easy to exploit, over all the game delivers on most fronts. At no point in the game does the story feel contrived or boring, keeping you on the edge of your seat the whole way. I highly reccommend this game if you are a fan of the series or just looking for a fun game to keep your interest.

reviewText: This is my favorite Final Fantasy.  It's not the best in the series but it's my favorite. reviewText: If you enjoyed playing Final Fantasy VIII on the PSX you should definitely consider getting this version.  It's nice to earn achievements along the way, plus the Steam version allows you to play Chocobo World, a mini-game not previously available in the US.  This version of the game does have a few downsides, however.  As many mention, the default music is subpar compared to the PSX version, so you would have to find a mod with the proper music files and install them.  Also, while the character models are cleaner looking than the PSX version, the backgrounds all seem to be a little lower quality.  They seem a bit more pixelated than I remember, which just stands out that much more against the various characters.  I've also noticed a few NPCs pixelating very badly at times.  First it was a nameless girl in the classroom at the beginning of the game, and shortly after Headmaster Cid turned into an unrecognizable blob of colored squares.  It doesn't seem to happen often, and I haven't noticed it happening to the various party characters.\n\nThis version has some flaws, but if you enjoyed playing the game in the past this is still worth snagging here on Steam, especially if you can catch it on a good sale.

reviewText:
This was the 2nd Final Fantasy game to originate on the original playstation. The first being Final Fantasy VII.

In this game you'll follow the journey of Squall from his start in Balamb Garden to wherever he and his friends end up as the story progresses. Many of the common Final Fantasy creatures return which are also known as Espers, Summons, or however each game in the series differentiates between them such as Ifrit or Shiva.

One of the shining qualities of this game is of course in my opinion the music which is done by Nobuo Uematsu.

For those new to the game: I'd suggest playing this for the story and the music. Also even though it's been out of style lately, the turned based combat system I still enjoy.

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VIII is one of my favourite RPGs and my favourite game in the Final Fantasy series.

The game is alot different from other RPGs due to the fact that magic must be taken from the enemies you battle and instead of mp you have a stock of all the magic you've taken

Magic spells are also the best way to increase your characters stats as enemies get stronger when you level up, and will end up stronger then you if you don't junction magic to your stats, as doing this will increase them (and can also make you extremely powerful.) It is this unique system that makes it one of my favourite RPGs.

The story is pretty good and will make you want to keep playing, around the middle the story feels to me like it was struggleing but it picked up again towards the end.

If you want a decent RPG to spend some time on, or are just looking for a unique RPG then you should give this game a shot!

reviewText: Final Fantasy VIII is a bit ridculous.\n\nNo, really - this game had a huge impact on me when I was 12 years old, so when I saw it up for grabs on Steam I acted fast. And you know what? Holy cow is this just goofy as hell. Of course, we should all be willing to admit that cliches are what FF is all about, and that's not a bad thing. It's just that VIII attempts to be a deconstruction and the story is frequently tripping and falling on its own and now a twist!" approach that gets a tad bit tired by the "disc 2" segment. That being said
date: I do enjoy the  settings as they're consistently well-rendered and imaginitive. I'd expect nothing less of the team from this era.\n\nThe characters? Pretty damn bland. There's a certain backstory that ties in importantly
recommended: but it doesn't really explain why (with the exception of a couple) these characters are all so ridiculous. Only Squall
hoursPlayed: the mainest of main characters

Putting the right spell on the right stat makes things so quickly breakable that it blew my mind how much trouble I had as a kid. Still

Stuff like this is why I've avoided strategy guides ever since I turned 14. It's going to be fun if you don't know exactly what item does what function.\n\nIn summation

reviewText:
One of the best game ever created is now on Steam and I had to buy it as soon as I saw it was available. The graphics are vastly improved and has two special features. A variation of the booster from VII makes an appearance but instead of making it a character booster it gives you 100 of level 1 and 2 magics. There is also a nice addition of Chocobo World, a mini game of Chocobo exploration, with items that you can use in FFVIII, that was never released outside of Japan.

The story is emotional, mysterious and thrilling and the music is beautiful. (Square has used low quality midi at the moment but most likely will be patched just as VII was.)

This is an essential for any Final Fantasy and RPG fan alike. This is one that must be played.

10/10

reviewText: The game is one of the under-appreciated game of the series. This game suffers being in the shadow of FFVII which in the time was a masterpiece. This game excels itself and I actually prefer this game to FFVII. One thing that FFVIII excelled over FFVII is the lead character.IMHO Squall is a much better protagonist than Cloud and he's one of the best of the series. You know what he's always thinking, and he's actually human compared to the other lead characters in the series. Throughout the game you can see his conflict in life caused by his troubled childhood. He wants to be alone because he's lost so much, he's not tough, deep inside he's weak and he cant accept losing anyone important to him, which is why he prefers to be alone, so he never has to lose anyone. The plot has many holes, but the overall story and the characters more than make up for it. The battle system is nothing like the other FFs. Drawing system to stock magic is a nuisance, and frankly it deters me from using magic completely, only for the sake of junctioning. The junctioning system has always divided opinion, but it is easily mastered if you put some effort into it and I really enjoy experimenting with each character's stat.Overall, this is a great game but the port is quite poor. The music for some reason is ported poorly and that is the main highlight of this game so if you do pick this game up,do something about it.

reviewText:
An (almost) direct port of one of the greatest PS1 games.
I'll break this up into three sections:

Overall gameplay:
Final Fantasy 8 continues the trend of the ATB gauge but with a few alterations:
Magic is no longer reliant on MP, but is stocked like an item by drawing it from either draw points hidden around the world, or from enemies.
The 'junctioning' system is an unusual beast:
It requires you to equip a summon (called Guardian Forces or GFs for short.)
Junctioning a GF allows your character to use more commands than just 'attack', such as items, magic, and the 'GF' command that allows you to call upon a junctioned GF to aid you in battle.
Junctioning also allows you to allocate magic to stats.
For instance, you can increase your physical or magical damage by junctioning a fire or thunder spell to that stat.

Weapons aren't purchased or acquired frequently, but require you instead to find weapon magazines which will list parts needed to remodel your current weapon into a more powerful model.
Weapons also allow for more limit breaks for your characters.
Most limit breaks are semi-controlable, allowing you to use certain inputs to boost damage or the like.

Summary- Very enjoyable, but the junctioning and magic drawing system may be daunting to those who aren't used to it.

Story:
You are a student at the military academy - Balamb Garden
Early in the game, you learn of the tyrannical president of the neighbouring region - Galbadia - and his plans for domination and war.
As the story progresses, you find that it goes much deeper than a president gone mad with power, and will fight to save the integrity of the world as you know it.
The main character; Squall, is a steriotypical loner. However, his dullness is counterbalanced by the colourful cast of allies that fight at his side.

Summary- Interesting story, good characters, will get you very engrossed... Until you get stuck and need to go grind, typical of most RPGs.

Port Quality -
If you're like me, and love your old favourite games, you would want them to be just as enjoyable as you remember.
This is where there are a few hitches -
If you've played the game before, the first noticeable difference will be the music quality.
It has been very dulled down from the original PS1 version.
This can be easily fixed with a mod, but shouldn't have been an issue in the first place.
The next is SFX.
For the most part, the SFX is the same, however, much of it has again been stripped and dulled down, most noticeable with the summoning animation of Quezacoatl.
Unfortunately, I can't find a fix for this and have had to just grit my teeth and bear with it.
My final gripe is that even though there is controller support, there is no omni-directional movement, making navigation difficult because you can only move in four different directionss, and the in-game tool-tips don't change their text if you have re-assigned the buttons.
For instance, if you have re-assigned 'B1' and 'B2', the game text will still read what the default setting was.

Summary- Overall port quality is poor.
The graphics and gameplay have remained consistant, but there are many issues.
These wouldn't be such an issue if they weren't so prominant.

Overall, I'd give this a game a 7/10.
It is very, very enjoyable, despite its faults.

reviewText: Final Fantasy VIII: HD, Triple-Tiad and Music\n\nWell, I finally bought Final Fantasy VIII for my PC and I'm glad I did, but there's one problem. After playing 7 and 8 for the first time on the PS3, I was so impressed by how these old games made me fall in love with its worlds and characters, it proved to me that AAA graphics, Sound design and even voice acting doesnt make a great game. By todays standards, these game are dated. When i first played FF VII last year I laughed at the terrible graphic, cheesey music and blocky characters. after destroying the first Mako reactor, I was hooked: The pre-rendered backgrounds looked beautiful, The music was emotional, and combat was rewarding and fun, the blocky characters still look bad. In short terms, I no longer look at these games based on their graphic's or age. FF VII is one great game, even by todays standards. theres a reason why everyone calls it the best. which brings me to FF VIII. Just like VII it was an excellent game. Not as mind blowing as VII, but still great. Playing the mini card game Triple-Triad was a blast. Can you believe it? I was playing a game......within a game (that was actually fun). Yes these games where so good, I decided to throw my money into Gabe's face and buy them both on Steam. FF VII = perfect PC port. HD graphic's, same music from PSX and achievements. The same could be said about FF VIII, everything is great, but the MUSIC!. Seriously, what the hell am i listening to? everything is a note too high or too low, it sound awful compared to PSX music. Its a real shame, because if you've already played the thing on PlayStation, then the music will stick out like a sore thumb. Apart from the sound issue, this is a great game to play. I just hope SquareEnix release Final Fantasy 9 on steam to make yet another game that much better. Just dont touch the sound. Kupo.

reviewText:
A great buy
Category        Score                Gameplay        8/10                Music        8/10                Graphics        8/10              Controls        5/10              Replayability        10/10          Overall Score        7.8/10
Perks
This game is a great port. Escellent in fact, but nothing is without flaws. Thank fully this game doesn't have too many of them. First lets look at some purchase perks. The game comes with baked in cheats, mods, acheivements, and chocobo world. To thouse who've played the original Chocobo World on it's own should be enough to want to purchase this remake as previously the only way to play it, and take advantage of the unique to the game items, were through cheats/hacks, or having a playstation pocket, and a playstation that could read it, so for this content alone you might be getting your money's worth. Next square enix has included acheivements. I don't have to tell you how achievements (or trophies if you think with a playstation mindset) didn't became mainstream until around 2005, so they are new and it gives you something to do along the way while playing, although there is plenty to do without them. The mods, are great. most importantly, the speed mod is great. If you've ever been pressed for time and not a lot of time for sitting through un-skippable cutscenes, or watching about 3-4 mins of traversing a map it definately comes in handy. Lastly the cheats. The game comes with some cheats built in such as the 100 spell cheat where you can draw a spell, and either press the cheat button, or save the game and run the cheat and you will have 100 of that spell. I haven't actually used any of the cheats, because I don't want to deprive myself of the bits of grinding here and there, but It's there if you need it.

Gameplay
Lots to love here. This game gives you options. No you will not have a different ending, but you have options to give yourself a different playthrough. The game levels itself up as you do, so you can play it a stratight shoot, or you can withold your level and work on crafting and farming items. You can grab the first magic that comes to mind, or you can be selective to carry the best magics. A lot of people will drill that the stat's suffer from using your stronger spells, but it's perception. I think of it as it expends energy to use the stronger spells making you weaker with use. With no GF challenges, or other self made playing challenges you can replay the game and have a whole different experience.

The cons
You've heard the positives now here are a few sour spots. The music. As you may have heard plenty beofre the musing isn't the best. It's heavily synthesized and sounds like a fan did all the music in their favorite mid player. It's the same as it was in the original game but with the concerts put out, most have grown acusomed to the higher level of music. It's a minor setback, one that could have been corrected by square enix much like the visual updates. The magic system. It is unique, and has a lot of give and take, but just as much as I applaud the using mgic drains your stats idea, the magic just isn't that strong. There aren't that many powerful spells, and because of it you're likely not to try creating any mages, or see your characters have much in differentiating stats. The controls for this port are bad, you can change your controls, but I haven't found out how to succesfully setup a controller, even with an xbox controller and support for them in the game. Even worse you can't turn off (or I haven't found out how to) controller controls and as you use your keyboard. In any dialogue that involves the controls the control controls display until you press, and/or hold down your keyboard keys. it's very frustrating.

Conclusion
As the title imples the game is defeinately a great buy due to the many perks, and how they way outweigh the cons.  If you want a very engrosing story, amazing cutscenes, music you will catch yourself humming to, Interesting gamign mechanics that offer plenty of replayability and hours upon hours of standard gameplay. Plenty of secrets, so much that you may need a guide or two to find them all. Lastly, the mini games chocobo world, and triple triad are good enough to be spinoffs of their own, and are beneficial, albeit optional, to the game. If you've been on the fence about it, or you have wanted to try it previously but haven't yet pick this one up or regret it.

reviewText: The game is one of the under-appreciated game of the series. This game suffers being in the shadow of FFVII which in the time was a masterpiece. This game excels itself and I actually prefer this game to FFVII. One thing that FFVIII excelled over FFVII is the lead character.IMHO Squall is a much better protagonist than Cloud and he's one of the best of the series. You know what he's always thinking, and he's actually human compared to the other lead characters in the series. Throughout the game you can see his conflict in life caused by his troubled childhood. He wants to be alone because he's lost so much, he's not tough, deep inside he's weak and he cant accept losing anyone important to him, which is why he prefers to be alone, so he never has to lose anyone. The plot has many holes, but the overall story and the characters more than make up for it. The battle system is nothing like the other FFs. Drawing system to stock magic is a nuisance, and frankly it deters me from using magic completely, only for the sake of junctioning. The junctioning system has always divided opinion, but it is easily mastered if you put some effort into it and I really enjoy experimenting with each character's stat.Overall, this is a great game but the port is quite poor. The music for some reason is ported poorly and that is the main highlight of this game so if you do pick this game up,do something about it.

reviewText:
An (almost) direct port of one of the greatest PS1 games.
I'll break this up into three sections:

Overall gameplay:
Final Fantasy 8 continues the trend of the ATB gauge but with a few alterations:
Magic is no longer reliant on MP, but is stocked like an item by drawing it from either draw points hidden around the world, or from enemies.
The 'junctioning' system is an unusual beast:
It requires you to equip a summon (called Guardian Forces or GFs for short.)
Junctioning a GF allows your character to use more commands than just 'attack', such as items, magic, and the 'GF' command that allows you to call upon a junctioned GF to aid you in battle.
Junctioning also allows you to allocate magic to stats.
For instance, you can increase your physical or magical damage by junctioning a fire or thunder spell to that stat.

Weapons aren't purchased or acquired frequently, but require you instead to find weapon magazines which will list parts needed to remodel your current weapon into a more powerful model.
Weapons also allow for more limit breaks for your characters.
Most limit breaks are semi-controlable, allowing you to use certain inputs to boost damage or the like.

Summary- Very enjoyable, but the junctioning and magic drawing system may be daunting to those who aren't used to it.

Story:
You are a student at the military academy - Balamb Garden
Early in the game, you learn of the tyrannical president of the neighbouring region - Galbadia - and his plans for domination and war.
As the story progresses, you find that it goes much deeper than a president gone mad with power, and will fight to save the integrity of the world as you know it.
The main character; Squall, is a steriotypical loner. However, his dullness is counterbalanced by the colourful cast of allies that fight at his side.

Summary- Interesting story, good characters, will get you very engrossed... Until you get stuck and need to go grind, typical of most RPGs.

Port Quality -
If you're like me, and love your old favourite games, you would want them to be just as enjoyable as you remember.
This is where there are a few hitches -
If you've played the game before, the first noticeable difference will be the music quality.
It has been very dulled down from the original PS1 version.
This can be easily fixed with a mod, but shouldn't have been an issue in the first place.
The next is SFX.
For the most part, the SFX is the same, however, much of it has again been stripped and dulled down, most noticeable with the summoning animation of Quezacoatl.
Unfortunately, I can't find a fix for this and have had to just grit my teeth and bear with it.
My final gripe is that even though there is controller support, there is no omni-directional movement, making navigation difficult because you can only move in four different directionss, and the in-game tool-tips don't change their text if you have re-assigned the buttons.
For instance, if you have re-assigned 'B1' and 'B2', the game text will still read what the default setting was.

Summary- Overall port quality is poor.
The graphics and gameplay have remained consistant, but there are many issues.
These wouldn't be such an issue if they weren't so prominant.

Overall, I'd give this a game a 7/10.
It is very, very enjoyable, despite its faults.

reviewText: Final Fantasy VIII: HD, Triple-Tiad and Music\n\nWell, I finally bought Final Fantasy VIII for my PC and I'm glad I did, but there's one problem. After playing 7 and 8 for the first time on the PS3, I was so impressed by how these old games made me fall in love with its worlds and characters, it proved to me that AAA graphics, Sound design and even voice acting doesnt make a great game. By todays standards, these game are dated. When i first played FF VII last year I laughed at the terrible graphic, cheesey music and blocky characters. after destroying the first Mako reactor, I was hooked: The pre-rendered backgrounds looked beautiful, The music was emotional, and combat was rewarding and fun, the blocky characters still look bad. In short terms, I no longer look at these games based on their graphic's or age. FF VII is one great game, even by todays standards. theres a reason why everyone calls it the best. which brings me to FF VIII. Just like VII it was an excellent game. Not as mind blowing as VII, but still great. Playing the mini card game Triple-Triad was a blast. Can you believe it? I was playing a game......within a game (that was actually fun). Yes these games where so good, I decided to throw my money into Gabe's face and buy them both on Steam. FF VII = perfect PC port. HD graphic's, same music from PSX and achievements. The same could be said about FF VIII, everything is great, but the MUSIC!. Seriously, what the hell am i listening to? everything is a note too high or too low, it sound awful compared to PSX music. Its a real shame, because if you've already played the thing on PlayStation, then the music will stick out like a sore thumb. Apart from the sound issue, this is a great game to play. I just hope SquareEnix release Final Fantasy 9 on steam to make yet another game that much better. Just dont touch the sound. Kupo.
