reviewText:
Final Fantasy VIII

RPG-Developed by SquareSoft / Square Enix
Year 1999/2000

The Story  8/10
You are Squall Leonhart an orphan and SeeD of Balamb Garden. SeeD is a mercenary group trained to fight the sorceress. You awake in the hospital wing after your training session with your fellow student Seifer. As your progress you go on your final exam to become a SeeD and be deployed around the whole world. Your first mission helping out a resistance faction. Sets you on a course that will change the entire world.

Grahpics 7/10
The graphic are better than Final Fantasy 7 fewer blocky textures. More movies they transition seemlessly between gameplay. The way monsters die is cool. Some will turn of stone or explode. Most just fall over and die I like that more than them turning red and dissappering like in Final Fantasy 7.  There are graphics mods that will improve the game if you can install them.

Music 0/10  after JunkyBiggs music mod 10/10

The music on this release of the game is poor... not of worry though it's a simple fix after you install the game just replace the muisc files with the converted ones thanks to JunkyBiggs. It takes less then 1 mintue to do this. Just look in the Guides section you will find his and many of music mods there.

The music in the game is amazing all the songs Eyes on Me" The Man with the Machine Gun" those are my favorites. The opening theme "Liberi Fatali"  The battle theme "Don’t Be Afraid" and the nice "Waltz For The Moon" all amazing. The songs all fit and game and fit what you are doing at the time.


Gameplay 10/10

The gameplay I love as it makes you have to think about what you are doing. In Final Fantasy 8 the monsters all level along with your party
date:
Their level is ramdonly decided as a few levels higher or lower than your average current partys level. If you had say Squall at level 100 and Zell at lvl 8 than monsters you run into would be from lv60-80.

Summons or Guardian Forces / GF

The GF play a major rule as they allow you to junction. The Junction system allows you to junction magic to your stats to makes yourself more powerful. Monsters do not level with your GF. It's really the base of the game it's easy to figure out and the in game tutorials explain it very well. The animations for the GF can become repetitive over time. Otherwise I really like this system myself it's fun and allows you to play the whole game without leveling at all.

Money / Gil

You are paid in this game based on your SeeD rank. Your SeeD rank is really based off of how many monsters you kill. There are a few other times in the story where doing your job right will up your rank but
recommended: not many. What I didn't like about this is that your rank falls after a short time. There are tests you can take to up your rank they as well. Making money becomes very
hoursPlayed:
very easy once you get GF tonberry. So don't worry about money after you get him and train him you will never run out of funds.

Chocobo World

Make sure you start using this as soon as you get boko from your first forest. Boko will make getting items very easy. Do not start chocobo world while Boko is set to Home. You will gltich the game and have to start over with a new boko. Just remeber to close chocobo world bring him home get his items and send him back before opening it agian. I'll save you some time the best ID is in fact "211" use the do over button till you get ID 211 it'll make the game much easier as boko will be a total pwnage machine.

The Card Game Triple Triad

I found triple Triad to be fun not challanging though. You are providing with cards of insane power by the time you get the GF brothers. Don't mix rules as they are very hard to get back to normal. The game is played on a 3x3 size board. You and your npc opponent start by selecting 5 cards and using the number rating and rules to flip and cards placed down. It's very simple and enjoying as long as you don't mess up and rule system. I'll say this again do not ever mix rules!

Chocobo Forests

I didn't like how they used chocobos in this final fantasy. After 7 had such fun with them all you can do in this one is ride them around the map. I would have liked to have had another race track or something along those lines sadly chocobos fall short in this game. I give the Chocobo Quest in this game a 3/10 it was boring.

I give this game a 8/10

I recommend you play it if you love RPGs"

reviewText: This is still one of my favorite Final Fantasy games, and the PC benefits over the PS1 are pretty nice. I love the ability to speed up the cinematics to 60 fps, which make the scenes look fantastic, although everything is moving at twice the speed, thus making it a much shorter cutscene, which is the closest thing to being able to skip it. But if you've already sunk hundreds of hours into it before, then it's definitely worth checking out, especially when it's on sale. If you havent played it before, its still definitely worth the money. The cutscenes still look good (for the time they were released, especially) and the overall game doesn't look too shabby compared to others from its time. The ability to summon GFs  (basically pets) and unlock loads of skills for then as well as everyone in the party is awesome. The magic/GF/Ability junction feature is also one of my favorite implemented systems, making it much easier to help overcome more powerful opponents once you've gotten used to utilizing it. Only downside to that is that you constantly need to stock magic in order to keep your stats as buffed as possible, which can take awhile and becomes a bit tedious. But overall, the mechanics are very smooth and simple. The story is very well done too. It's enough of a driving factor to keep people who may not like grinding very much to stay interested, although there's no journal or anything of that nature to keep you focused on where to go next, which may become a problem if you decide to stop playing for a while and resume later. That's one of my only real problems with this game. Most adventure/open world games have some sort of journal or objective list in case you forget where you're supposed to go next, or at least who to talk to. That aside, I'd still highly recommend this game to just about anyone who loves the old school RPG style of game play with some unique mechanics and a good storyline.\n\nTL;DR Buy this game. It's a great part of the FF series.

reviewText:
At first, this game took me a while to get into due to the strange magic and stat system as well as the general world of the game, but I ended up surprising myself by how likable it ended up being.

In this game, you can gather magic spells from enemies via battle command, and then recast the spells, or equip them onto your stats to make them increase. This felt like a very weird system, having to gather and collect spells just to cast them later, as well as how slow you'd gather the spells. I later learned that the higher your magic stat, the faster your magic gathering would become, and I also learned that magic generally wouldn't be used a lot in normal combat anyways, so you'd rarely touch your huge pile of magic spells unless a boss or healing.

What really makes me like this system is equipping the spells to your stats, since the more magic you have of that type you're attaching to a specific stat (maximum 100 stack of any spell), the higher boost that stat would recieve. It also takes into account what kind of magic is being placed onto the stat, so placing something like... haste onto your speed stat would give it a massive boost. Casting spells equipped to your stats would cause that stat to lower, due to a smaller stack being there now, so you might end up finding a use for many spells you'd never even give the chance in other FF games.

I've personally only played FF4, 5, 6, and 7 (as well as this game), but I find this manages to be my second favourite, even beating out games I have a nostalgic feeling for. A well-written and interesting story, wonderful soundtrack (even though I think this port has a different one, but I haven't heard the original), and a cast of characters I ended up warming up to the same as the protagonist. If you haven't played this, I strongly recommend you give it a try if you're into turn-based" RPGs
date: since it was a wonderful experience for only $12."

reviewText: I played this game many years back on the PS2 during high school with one of my friends. We would come back home after school and progress slowly through the game. I remember how much we struggled with Mobile Type 8 the first time around  when we thought GFs were the way to go. FF8 was the first FF I played and it is my favorite. I have played every single FF game since FFIII and have always enjoyed the series (not so much the MMO variants). I have lost count how many times I beat this game on the PS2 and later using epsxe. I had save files where I literally maxed every stat on all characters. While I did not go quite that crazy this time around, playing FF8 on steam was a lot of fun. I took it much slower this time due to work and other obligations, but the game brought back a lot of old memories. The only aspect of FF8 I wish was different is how easy all aspects of the game (including Omega weapon) are once you have some tricks down. I enjoyed trying the various kick a** combos I had tried in the past. Squall/Rinoa/Zell (or Irvine) make the absolute best team. Nothing beats Rinoa's Angel Wing if she is junctioned properly with 255 magic and only Meteor and curative/support spells she won't cast while in Angel Wing (well unless you can guarantee Squall's Renzokuken goes Lion Heart everytime). And Irvine or Zell make great support. Or the triple Squall/Irvine/Zell combo is awesome too with more control (since Rinoa control is lost with Angel Wing limit) but less damage. Or even lesser damage combos with Quistis (great for non-boss mobs or even just utility) and Selphie. Playing around with various character combos was a blast :) While FF8 is not the most popular FF, it is definitely my favorite.

reviewText: I hesitantly reccomend this game. It doesn't measure up to what Square Enix promised (audio quality is a massive issue; .MIDI music, poor sound effects) but overall it does play well. If you're wanting to jump into Final Fantasy, however, don't let this be your introduction to the series. The battle system in this particular title is one of the most complicated in the series and is not newbie friendly. So if you're not used to turn based RPGs, or even Final Fantasy in general, I would reccomend starting with 7 (which is also on Steam for a similar price). This is a good game but does not upscale to higher resolutions very well at all. It looks its best at 800x600, which is sad. It's a lazy port, but it plays well and is still a lot of fun.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Having played this game when it first came out, I decided to go for the nostalgia bomb and try it on computer. I must say the designers (or whoever prepared this version) did a really nice job making the controls computer-friendly.

As for the game itself, I love it. It's a great addition to the Final Fantasy series and allows you to tailor your characters any way you want. None of them have a predisposition for a type of activity (black magic, white magic, thief), so it's up to you to decide which stats they gain.

I'm also impressed how well the graphics have held up. I suppose the resurgance of 8-bit homage games have helped, but it's always easy to tell how the characters are feeling. To me, that's such a great part of this game.

reviewText:
To preface, this is now the third time I have bought FF8.  I own a disc version for PSX, a digital classics for PS3, and now this for Steam.  This rerelease is basically a very very minimially touched up rerelease of the original PC version.  Graphically it's mildly better, the audio sounds mildly worse (although I believe there are mods to get the psx audio installed,) and they have added cheating to help deal with the magic grinding.

To anyone who has not played an PSX generation Final Fantasy (7, 8, 9) they're all worth the time to play through and generally all have their own faults.  FF8 is generally very easy to beat, but does require substantial grinding, so the built in Magic Boost" is a nice touch to make the game a bit less of a chore.

In general
recommended: give this one a shot.  For all of its plot holes and grinding
hoursPlayed: it's a game that offers quite a few hours of play for not a whole lot of money.  For me

reviewText:
I think this game was well made for it's time. It has its ups and downs but the pros seem to outweight the cons for me.

Firstly, graphics were pretty much make everything as 3D as possible" and was a nice step up from simply having characters move around on a set background. One could easily tell from even simple places that they tried to put as much detail as possible into things.

The cutscenes were rather nice for their time and if you pay attention near the end of Disc 1 (the parade) you'll notice the dance being done is very similar to Michael Jackson's Thriller dance. Another moment of hilarious in hindsight is a phrase Selphie tried to get going. "Booyaka!"
date: guess which WWE wrestler would make that his catchphrase a couple of years later?\n\nThe battle system was different and kept the game at a challenging level
recommended: almost everything (save for a few bosses with levelc caps) leveled up as you did. This could be good or bad depending on how skilled of a player you are. If you play it well enough you can pretty much level up quickly right after obtaining Siren (Life-RF skill yourself Zombies + Life/Full-Life and go fight some T-Rexuar).\n\nWhile keeping a low level is generally advised to keep the game easy
hoursPlayed: going to over level 40 as early as disc 1 can prove helpful by getting some of the best skills in the game to junction to your characters making the rest of the game a cakeqalk (Junction either 100 Quakes or Ultima to Attack and say good-bye to difficulty~).\n\nThe music was excellent. Most of the music would fit the mood
voteText: although sometimes cheerful music would continue to play during times where it suddenly became very unfitting (nothing new there actually). The battle and boss music is what has always stuck out the most to me though
helpfulPercent: it always made me feel pumped and excited to keep playing the game.\n\nThe GFs were also another fun factor
votesHelpful: some had really humorous attack animations (Tonberry
votesTotal: Cactuar
votesFunny: or the Brothers) while others could be downright frightening or strange (Eden
commentsCount: Doomtrain
column16: or Diabolos (imagine a giant dark matter sphere crushing you into nothing!)). The junctions and abilities they give are incredibly helpful. However I tended to always need to make one of them forget SumMagic 10% to add a more needed ability such as HP-J or the coveted and rare Ability - x4 (Rosetta Stones are very hard to come by and unless you can find more than the one at Ultimecia's Castle
column17: only the person with Bahamut will get the full benefit).\n\nOverall
column18: I think this game was great for it's time and while the Romance theme is a bit strong
column19: the game managed to remain fun to me then and still does now. 8.5/10
column20: would recommend to others."

reviewText: FFVIII is my absolute FAVOURITE Final Fantasy game of them all. It starts off a bit slow, but once you get into the plot and get used to the battle system, it can get really intense really fast. It's also a lot of fun to run around the world and fight extra bosses and upgrade weapons and, of course, play Triple Traid (once you understand the rules, of course). The plot is good, the animation is good considering when it came out, and the music is, as usual, perfectly written to suit the scenery and moments in-game.

reviewText:
Yes I reccomend this game to Anyone that lieks the Final Fantasy Series, The Originals that is. This game is turn based, and it comes in the format of somewhat of a romantic novel between a Soldier and a Faction Leader. I Highly reccomend that You take your time reading and please for your own sake DO NOT RUSH, you will miss out on a breath taking story and its world; And i do mean this DO NOT RUSH.

This is my favorite Final Fantasy in the series, and yes i played 9, 10 , and reasonably 7 [i will get back to it].

Anyway here it goes:

The Graphics.. don't give a damn about it, this isnt a remake is re-release of the game. Still love the original one on PS1

The Audio: It was very interesting to hear the MIDI structure Nobuo Uematsu put together, I was able to tell how he approached the themes, and where he could have possibly had trouble playing. [ Check out EDEA's Theme i believe is called sucession of witches, or the sucessor. Also check out Balamb's theme you would hear a  dissonant sound from both themes. So from musician to musician it was very exiting to hear what the next track would sound like in MIDI :D. Though I like the MIDI version in its own way, the orchestrated versions of the OST is by far better, and i mean waaaaay better.

[b]The Gameplay:[/b] Turn based, OR NOT really. There is  ATB which is Active Time battle and you can basically bump this all the way up and it wont feel turn based. what this does is that it makes the battle waiting faster, and as you level up so do your sorroundings so it will be even faster! The magic in this game is not learned as an ability but drawn from Draw points and or monsters, and they do not take away any magic power, or MP, but they are stored in Quantities. To some this might be an abomination BUT to me this feels a bit interesting and maybe, challenging, because you will then learn not to waste magic, lets say you have for instance 10 curagas or 5 Meltdowns....ehheheh. you best use them wisely. I also love the Junction system because this gives the characters and the GFs more uniqueness, enough said.

[b]One con[/b], and this is a big one for me, I DO NOT LIKE THE MAGIC BOOSTER, i think that takes away from the game, and also encourages people to cheat, which in my opinion  is a bad thing to do, because it takes away from the experience & who would want to cheat with such a good game? this turns off people.

[b]On a side note[/b] if they were to do more Final Fantasy remakes' they should add an option that Filters the graphics of these games, they arent demanding anyways, to give them different tones.. that would be very very very cool.

I will highly reccomend this game , dont worry about what people say about this title, everyone has their own taste,

[b]10/10 - Personally[/b]
.. Oh yeah & PLEASE IF YOU ARE A FF NEWBIEGO PLAY CLASICS LIKE THIS FIRST.

reviewText: Where do I begin? I've never been a huge fan of final fantasy with 8 being the only one in the series that I've beaten. To put it simply I love this game and it pairs up with Dragon Quest 8, another game by Square Enix that i absolutely love. I'll start off by saying Squall has to be one of the best characters I've seen in a long time and the character development of Squall over the course of FF8 is nothing short of spectacular. The love story is brilliant and anybody whos beaten the game and seen the ending you know how amazing it is. The reason I like Squall so much is that I can relate to him and being able to relate to the main protagonist of any game is a good thing. My favortie scene would have to be Squall and Rinoa on the ragnorak with the eyes on me theme song for the game playing. Truly beautiful scene. reviewText:
- I never had the chance to finish this game, until now. I liked. You can't compare with Final Fantasy VII, but still worth playing. Sadly, it lacks of real markable characters. There are some interesting fellas, but nothing too much special. Squall saves the game. His own conflits are very interesting. Kinda remind me a little of Cloud Strike. There is a nice romance (a little corny but I can live with that), an amazing soundtrack and a lot of cool missions.

Plus, when I was fighting the last boss, the game ran pretty slow during almost half of the battle. Like lagging. I dunno if there's something related to the music mod that I installed. But it was only on that fight.

8/10

reviewText:
I think this game gets overshadowed by its predecessor. This game is inventive for the seventh sequel of any game. Without spoiling to much, the story is unpredictable (well, sometimes very predictable) due to not knowing what your doing half the time. The gameplay in battle is well made, giving you may options for attacking. The characters are diverse, they're personality spanning from highly motivated to just bored. Although the gameplay outside of battle is much worse though. Random encounters are frequent, which wouldn't be a problem if half the time your weren't either looking for something that gives you no clue as to where it is, or running back and forth, rellaying messages between characters, cusing encounters constantly. Overall, the graphics are MUCH better than FFVII, which was pretty much the only thing FFVII got wrong. Maybe MUCH is a bit of a leap, but the models are slightly more polygonal, but the backrounds look... meh, at best. But the story and characters are what won me over. I may just have bad taste, but I'm impressed by this game.

7/10

I think that for the price, it is worth experiencing the last in the trilogy of SquareEnix's best games.

reviewText:
Yes I reccomend this game to Anyone that lieks the Final Fantasy Series, The Originals that is. This game is turn based, and it comes in the format of somewhat of a romantic novel between a Soldier and a Faction Leader. I Highly reccomend that You take your time reading and please for your own sake DO NOT RUSH, you will miss out on a breath taking story and its world; And i do mean this DO NOT RUSH.

This is my favorite Final Fantasy in the series, and yes i played 9, 10 , and reasonably 7 [i will get back to it].

Anyway here it goes:

The Graphics.. don't give a damn about it, this isnt a remake is re-release of the game. Still love the original one on PS1

The Audio: It was very interesting to hear the MIDI structure Nobuo Uematsu put together, I was able to tell how he approached the themes, and where he could have possibly had trouble playing. [ Check out EDEA's Theme i believe is called sucession of witches, or the sucessor. Also check out Balamb's theme you would hear a  dissonant sound from both themes. So from musician to musician it was very exiting to hear what the next track would sound like in MIDI :D. Though I like the MIDI version in its own way, the orchestrated versions of the OST is by far better, and i mean waaaaay better.

[b]The Gameplay:[/b] Turn based, OR NOT really. There is  ATB which is Active Time battle and you can basically bump this all the way up and it wont feel turn based. what this does is that it makes the battle waiting faster, and as you level up so do your sorroundings so it will be even faster! The magic in this game is not learned as an ability but drawn from Draw points and or monsters, and they do not take away any magic power, or MP, but they are stored in Quantities. To some this might be an abomination BUT to me this feels a bit interesting and maybe, challenging, because you will then learn not to waste magic, lets say you have for instance 10 curagas or 5 Meltdowns....ehheheh. you best use them wisely. I also love the Junction system because this gives the characters and the GFs more uniqueness, enough said.

[b]One con[/b], and this is a big one for me, I DO NOT LIKE THE MAGIC BOOSTER, i think that takes away from the game, and also encourages people to cheat, which in my opinion  is a bad thing to do, because it takes away from the experience & who would want to cheat with such a good game? this turns off people.

[b]On a side note[/b] if they were to do more Final Fantasy remakes' they should add an option that Filters the graphics of these games, they arent demanding anyways, to give them different tones.. that would be very very very cool.

I will highly reccomend this game , dont worry about what people say about this title, everyone has their own taste,

[b]10/10 - Personally[/b]
.. Oh yeah & PLEASE IF YOU ARE A FF NEWBIEGO PLAY CLASICS LIKE THIS FIRST.

reviewText:
A classic to play again.  The graphics have been improved upon, I'd say more but for those of you who played this when it was brand new, I will save the description so that you can see for youself.  A personal favorite of mine of all of the final fantasy story lines.  Game play seems a little simplified from the original game play version in that commands for the gunblade as well as other small functions in the game and it is enough of an improvement that it makes the game much kinder to a first time final fantasy player.

Final Fantasy is hard to get wrong, especially the originals but if you're new to the final fantasy experience I would recommend getting into it with these older versions as learning how the game works in these versions is easier and allows you to learn quickly when moving on to the newer versions of the game (you dont feel as lost when you know what you're doing).

Final Fantasy VIII's story line is one of the more light hearted ones so if you're looking for one that is feel good, this is one of the few.  I would recommend this game to any one and especially to RPG fans out there.  If you have not played it yet you really are missing out.  The game is fun, chok full of 90's jokes♥♥♥♥♥♥ances and of course as with all Final Fantasy games, look forward to the grind ;).

reviewText:
What more is there to say. It is a re-release with very little changes, and some slight graphical upgrades, but only slight. Par for the course for Square Enix. Square Enix, you are reading this, please for the love of GabeN give these old ps1 titles a proper re-texture job please. Love them for their mechanics and story, but holy Cid could these use an update.

Now if only they would release IX and X International on the PC. They can keep X-2 on the consoles though.  Square, if you do this, you have instant access to my wallet. Shameful i know, but there you have it.

All in all, i give the game a 4/5. It's not my favorite of the series, but it is good none the less, and definitely worth the purchase if you have not played the games before. That being said. Square enix REALLY needs to start thinking about their customers who have already bought all the other versions, even the original PC releases of 7 and 8. For us, this is almost a worthless purchase other than to say we have it legally on PC. Why do i say that? Well, mostly because all of these ps1 title re-rereleases can be played on an emulator, and sometimes with better resolution and even sometimes some extra texture filters. These are things that not even Square enix bothers to deliver on.

So, is this game worth a purchase. Sure. But understand that you really aren't getting much more than a quick re-release of an old game that already is playable in some other way, and in some cases, at even better quality. AND without having to log on to some server.........

Just saiyan......

reviewText:
Final Fantasy 8 is another classic from Square and it's wonderful to finally see it on Steam.

The only problem is...this port is pretty lazy.  The first thing you'll notice is the music quality is garbage.  Square Enix decided to use the MIDI soundtrack files instead of the original Playstation tracks so from the first second you start up the game you'll notice the sloppiness of the PC version.  Luckily this is a pretty easy fix.  Just download the original Playstation soundtrack files and replace what's already in there - it doesn't even break achievement support.  That said, that just goes to show how really lazy this port to Steam was if they couldn't even be bothered fixing the audio quality for their target audience.

Another huge issue for me is the controller support is pretty subpar.  Instead of full integration with an Xbox / Playstation controller they use the B1"
hoursPlayed: etc. system.  Normally this wouldn't be a huge issue
voteText: but there are many times in the game that this type of controller support is extremely aggravating.  For example
helpfulPercent: Zell's limit break is all about hitting the proper buttons on your gamepad
votesHelpful: but if they're labeled arbitrarily it doesn't work out so well.  The Timber mission also has you pressing buttons and entering codes and when you can't correlate those codes back to controller buttons it adds a level of aggravation.  You also can't map the D-PAD or triggers
votesTotal: so you're forced to walk around with the Joystick.\n\nIn addition to the above controller issue
votesFunny: there's an integrated launcher that requires you to use the mouse to enter the game instead of just taking you to the title when you start from the Steam client
commentsCount: and before you can actually start or continue a game you need to press the "B1" on the keyboard one final time before an attached controller will accept input - if you're playing on a couch (like I do) this involves a lot of switching between controllers until you finally get into the game - to make this worse
column16: if your controller disconnects for any reason (let it sit idle too long) then you need to quit and restart the game before you can use that input option again.  In addition to the above
column17: mapping the controls is both a mixture of in-launcher
column18: and in the config menu of the game itself.  I found myself struggling with getting the controls right by messing in the config menu
column19: quitting
column20: adjusting in the launcher
column21: and then tooling around in the config menu again for over an hour before I had it right.\n\nGranted
column22: Square Enix put "Partial Controller Support" for this title
column23: but it doesn't seem like it would take too long to fix the controller support (and replace the sound files in the installer).\n\nI'm recommending FF8 because it's a good game
column24: I'm pleased to see it come to PC
column25: and the MIDI file type is an easy fix - but really Square Enix
column26: step up your game with these ports or I'll stick to emulation."

reviewText: Final Fantasy VIII, on steam, just as in 1999, fails considerably to equal its predecessor and yet still manages to be one of the best RPGs ever created. The graphics, in a different style, seem to have aged terribly on our HD monitors today. But this can take little away from the beautifully crafted world and pretty interesting (if rather unnecessarily confusing) storyline. Cards are still a blast to play and remain one of the best side-games to this day. Final Fantasy VIII is well worth another look on PC, although the mods are neither as plentiful nor as comprehensive as those for VII, this is perhaps also due to the fact that it was released much more recently. If you're looking solely for a nostalgia trip to 90s Final Fantasy, the 8th installment of the series is a very, very solid title, but I'd still always recommend its predecessor. 9/10.\n

Its the first one I can remember that has Mini-game built it and its fun,simple and addicting to play. reviewText: The only other game I enjoyed nearly as much as this as a kid was Xenogears. This game is the reason why i like video games. Getting lost in a world, getting to know interesting characters. hours upon hours of leveling up, exploring, fighting scary monsters and looking like a badass while doing it all. I could go on for hours about why i personally love this game, but i wont. If your up for spending time with a classic RPG worth it, then by all means do i reccomend this game to you. I could not be happier to dive back into the world of Final Fantasy 8.\n\nThough i am happy to be able to support the release of the game a fifth time. This version is not without it's flaws. This is not a port of the PSX version, but of the PC version, the visuals are a bit different and the Music is not nearly as good as the original Playstation version. If you have a Psp,Vita,Ps3, or even a Playstation you're better off getting the real Final Fantasy 8 experience there. Either way, I hope you enjoy the game.

reviewText:
After FF7 I was rly excited to play FF8 on steam after unbelievable 15 years :D I remember having loved this game and I was curious what I would think about it after so many years.

As in all Squaresoft (Square Enix) RPGs you can spend A LOT of time playing this game and some sidequests are rather annoying but if u dont ant to play them then just dont :)

The game itself isnt rly difficult...well obviously it depends on your characters skill but I got through without any big problems. Though there are some tough enemies which you dont have to kill but u will feel great after defeating them.

Again the battlesystem is quite goood. You should speed it up in the menu though then u wont have to wait ages for each character to have a go. Magic isnt used by junctioning special materia to your character like in FF7. Here u have to collect the spells. U can either draw them from enemies or refine them (quickest way is refining them). U will have access to the open world pretty fast and can go exploring. Story takes place in pretty calm and colourful world. You can use magic for the battles and have the possibilty to summon Monsters to help you out.

You are a soldier of SeeD a special force who fights against witches. Yeah... witches... but luckily not the medieval witches :D They r just mean rly mean women with exceptional power who always want more... (sounds familiar?).

Main focus, next to saving the world, is the rather complicated relation between the main character and one of his clients. Yes! This is an epic lovestory :D

The characters can be annyoing from time to time but after long speeches u will be rewarded with awesome cutscenes :D

All in all I enjoyed playing the game after 15 years and it is the second best RPG Squaresoft (Square Enix) has developed :D

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VIII works hard to address a lot of the design issues present in the previous game - save points are present in better locations, the world map now has roads you can travel to avoid constant enemy encounters, the tutorials are detailed (in some cases too-detailed), the minigames are less frustrating.

In saying that, the game is technically poorer than the PS1 version in terms of both visuals and audio. The soundtrack is good, but it's no FFVII, and the cheap midi sounds are jarring when compared to the PS1 version. The pre-rendered backgrounds have very low resolution, and the characters stand out starkly against the world around them. The greater articulation and realism given to the character models is a blessing and a curse - their gestures are much more varied and identifiable, but the stylised actions and humour of the characters clashes with the life-like designs. The cuteness of FFVII's characters allowed a sense of humour and slapstick that doesn't comfortably carry over into this more realistic design, and leaves some moments feeling awkward, as if the designers couldn't quite meet the goal they were aiming for.

In contrast to FFVII, the game world opens up almost immediately, and rewards the player generously in terms of money. The 'Junction' system of battle is quite confusing to begin with, and may be prohibitively overwhelming for those with little patience, but once one learns the ins and outs of the system, the variation it allows makes the FFVII system feel like button-mashing child's play. The abolition of 'magic points', in favour of 'drawing' spells from the enemy and the environment is a refreshing change, and makes the battles feel less restrictive as you can more-or-less cast away to your heart's content, rather than constantly worrying about refilling the MP bar.

One feature I don't quite like is effectively making the summoned Guardians a default attack - watching their stunningly cinematic (and lengthy) attacks is fun for the first few times, but gets really tedious after a while, to the point that I could set one attack for each character, and then surf the web while all the cinematics played.

All in all, the gameplay is a noticable improvement over FFVII, although it comes a distant second in terms of audio-visual quality. Hopefully these issues are addressed at some point, but who knows. It doesn't kill the game for me, and FFVIII is much easier to pick up and play than its predecessor, but they are both worthy additions to the series, and were iconic games of their time.

reviewText: The gameplay is pretty good. To make your characters stronger you use a junction system where you will equip magic to your stats. reviewText:
Fantastic game on par with Final Fantasy VII. The Final Fantasy series has been around since the dawn of the gamer age and many RPGs have been modeled after the success of this series. Final Fantasy VIII is no exception. It is to this day a masterpiece that  captures the imagination and brings one into an epic and unique universe.

Pros:
Great gameplay - The junction system allows for magic and summons to effect the stats your characters have depending on how strong and what type of magic is placed into which stat slot. There is an open world to explore, which can allow access to towns and secret locations. This feature was removed from Final Fantasy X onwards.

Unique Story - When this game was on the Playstation 1 it was 4 discs long. The game starts off with a cut scene followed by putting you straight into the action where you must complete a trial to obtain your third (you gain the first 2 from the computer room) Guardian Force. The game does an excellent job at character development and allows you to literally read what the protagonist, Squall is thinking.

Cons:
Dated graphics: While its true this is an old game, the graphics are still respectable and wont burn your eye lids off looking at.

No voice acting: You have to be ready to read a lot of text because theres no voice acting.


Conclusion:
Overall this game is a GEM and must have for anyone who enjoys Final Fantasy or classic RPG's.

reviewText: The Port: The Steam port is a mixed bag. It has some pretty glaring flaws. First of all, you can't change the controls in-game (only in the pre-game menu). Secondly, the pre-game menu has a very big CHEAT HERE!!!! sign that allows you to bypass all kinds of things you'd normally have to earn yourself (money, spell inventory, etc.). Thirdly, the music they included are the awful MIDI files that are terribly low quality. You can fix this (one of the top-rated posts includes the link), but it's a needless hassle. On the plus side, the graphics look pretty good and the game includes ChocoWorld, which we PSX users never got. So like I said, it's a mixed bag. If you still have this on the PC with ChocoWorld, there's absolutely no reason to get the Steam release. If, however, you had it on PSX and would like to play ChocoWorld and use the items/characters from that side game in the main game, you might be interested in picking this up when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Oh man, where do I start!?

Final Fantasy 8 was my introduction, and my gateway, to gaming. I loved this game and spent hundreds of hours playing it as an angsty teenager. It has everything an RPG fan could want;

- Epic story
- 100+ hours of content
- Engaging characters that you can really grow to care about
- A junction (stat enhancing) system that can be broken/abused to generally hilarious effect (I once had every character being continually healed by all elemental damage)
- TCG minigame

I strongly urge anyone who has ever considered getting this game, is in the market for a classic or just has some spare cash to play with (especially if this goes on sale!) to buy this game. I loved playing it again as an adult, I think I probably will for years to come!

reviewText: Final Fantasy VIII is a tale of sorceress wars, romance, and the ties of friendship that bring people together in the timeless tale of heroes vs villians. The characters are fun, different and the story is immersive, allowing you freedom to choose how you boost your stats and what abilities you can use with the unique Junction system. Recommended to all who love the Final Fantasy series, or for those who enjoy the JRPG genre :3. While the PC version's music leaves a lot to be desired, there is an easy fix found in the FFVIII Steam forums called Roses and Wine. A simple way to retrieve the beautiful Playstation version music fans remember and newbies will appreciate.

reviewText: It's no mystery to any of my friends, Final Fantasy VIII is my favorite game of all time. While this is largely due to the huge amount of nostalgia I have for the game that I spent just about every weekend of my childhood playing, FF8 is a game I still find myself playing to completion nearly 6 times a year. The Steam version is something i've been waiting for for some time, being someone who uses their PC more than any console. The remastered version does include some much needed brightness and sharpness to the every character model in the game, as well as redone portraits for the party members and guardian forces. However, the remastered version isnt without flaws. The music is not the original PS1 quality music, and is largely replaced by shoddier midi files that are less that are far from perfect, especially when compared to Nobuo's epics. The other drawback is that the Overworld looks just absolutely terrible. I'm not sure why the overworld looks as bad as it does, but it's pretty unforgivable, fortunatly you wont be spending too much time there. Fortunatly, both of these porting issues can be addressed through mods. The new addition also features a Magic Booster" to help players struggling with the content

reviewText:
Ahhh finally a good PC version of this game. I am glad I added this to my collection.

After reading some reviews, I was concerned that this version was bad, but it seems that some of the complaints were a little misplaced in my opinion.



Sound
So here is the weird thing, everything sounds like the familiar way it is supposed be. Wav, midi, and old PS1 style. No HD Remastered sound effects or music, this is a good thing to me in this case. If you have problems, you may need to update drivers or your midi set. The orginal PC game had to install Yamaha Extensive MIDI sound library just to get the sounds to work (needless to say, you do not have to go through that trouble anymore).



Graphics
I have not tried the orginal mode, but I can clearly see what is going on. Some people might not know how bad a game designed for 4:3 CRT TVs look like on a 1080p screen, but overall this is a lot better than when it was orginally released. However there are some spots that look silly. You will know them when you see them. Take a deep breath and just keep playing

But the biggest suprise for me, is the overall FMV quality. I am very pleased with this because the FMV in the orginal PC release is more choppy on the recommend 800x600 (for the time).



Controls
I would recommend using a controller, but it is optional. The direction movement is only 8 ways, true to its orginal version. If this puts you off, then this is not the game for you.



Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who would enjoy an old jrpg from the 1990s. If you are worried about HD grapics and remaster music, then this game is not for you.

Also you will need a facebook account or a square/enix to sign in once before playing this. So make sure you have internet access the first time you start this. After that, you should be good.

reviewText:
Oh man, where do I start!?

Final Fantasy 8 was my introduction, and my gateway, to gaming. I loved this game and spent hundreds of hours playing it as an angsty teenager. It has everything an RPG fan could want;

- Epic story
- 100+ hours of content
- Engaging characters that you can really grow to care about
- A junction (stat enhancing) system that can be broken/abused to generally hilarious effect (I once had every character being continually healed by all elemental damage)
- TCG minigame

I strongly urge anyone who has ever considered getting this game, is in the market for a classic or just has some spare cash to play with (especially if this goes on sale!) to buy this game. I loved playing it again as an adult, I think I probably will for years to come!

reviewText: Final Fantasy VIII is a tale of sorceress wars, romance, and the ties of friendship that bring people together in the timeless tale of heroes vs villians. The characters are fun, different and the story is immersive, allowing you freedom to choose how you boost your stats and what abilities you can use with the unique Junction system. Recommended to all who love the Final Fantasy series, or for those who enjoy the JRPG genre :3. While the PC version's music leaves a lot to be desired, there is an easy fix found in the FFVIII Steam forums called Roses and Wine. A simple way to retrieve the beautiful Playstation version music fans remember and newbies will appreciate.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game defined my childhood, it was also one of the only reasons i ever turned on my PS1. The soundtrack is probably the best of any game i've ever played, the gameplay was exactly what you'd expect of an FF game with a battle and junction system that is one of the best in the series but above all that the story is what makes this such a standout in the series, i haven't found many RPG's outside this era where i actually gave more than half a ♥♥♥♥ about the story or the plethora of poorly developed one dimensional characters that came with them.

This version is kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ with the MIDI music. The DRM is not an issue as you just need register once for a SQE account and you can play offline, mod, cheat and generally do whatever you want afterwards. It also looks a hell of a lot better than the original PC (and PSX) release, the backgrounds obviously aren't improved but the character models, attack, GF and spell animations are all greatly improved by the increased resolution support.

I played this when it was first relased on steam and at the time there weren't alot of mods available besides Roses&Wine which is a must for improving the audio but some of the mods that are available now make the game look a hell of a lot better and i'll definately be using them next time.

For old FF lovers, like me, its nice to have this game on PC, forever. Cant wait to see FF IV on PC, fingers crossed :)

reviewText:
Final Fantasy VIII is my favourite game not only in its own series, but jRPGs as a whole. The characters, more modern/realistic tone, romance centric plot, Nobuo Uematsu's music (man with the machine gun? force your way? the extreme?) and a heavy dose of nostalgia earn it that. So you would think I was excited when I heard that it was coming to Steam - and I was - until I heard it was just a port of the original PC release.

The MIDI music in this game is a DOWNGRADE of the music on the Playstation 1. The menus are... ugly and look really weird. I don't mean to be that person, but the graphics aren't doing so well either. Gamepad support isn't all there. You need a Square Enix account to play the game. And before I find something else to complain about, if you have a similar experience as me, you might have incompatibility issues with more recent Windows releases, or the Steam overlay/achievements.

But hey, it has Chocobo World. That's nifty.

Just buy the original game, whether that's on the PS1, PS3, or PSP. If you absolutely have to have it on PC, look into mods to fix the music and menus, at the very least.

reviewText:
Let me just get this out of the way, this game is fantastic. In fact I rate it higher than that other Final Fantasy that seems to get more attention. Maybe you agree with me or maybe you disagree but let me at least give you a couple of reasons that you shouldn't shy away from this gem. This game is unique and it is that same uniqueness that makes this game shine. Forget all the bad stuff people say about this game. Lets instead focus on the good that this game does.

Final Fantasy 8 did some wonderful things that no other FF title did. One of the most basic of JRPG principles, grinding battles. Well in short you don't need to really fight anything. I mean you can level up your charactors but there really isn't any real incentive to do it. For starters you are a student and you take a test early in the game. This test determines you pay or salary. Plus if you don't do so hot on the test you don't get a high salary. You can retake the test to do better and get paid more as well. So no need to really grind mobs for money as you get paid at regular intervals just like a job. I believe this is a plus as it allows for me to explore the world and without the need to stop and fight over and over. Also note, that bosses do not give out EXP at all. So theoretically, you could go thru the game at the starting level if you really wanted to.

So lets talk about the leveling system in the game, another plus to FF8's formula. The game uses a scaling system, which means the higher level you are the mobs scale to always give a challange of sorts. Which in every other game is a bad. I truely despise level scaling. It defeats the purpose of leveling to get stronger but this game bring a happy medium to play. FF8 intruduces the Junction System". This entails a few things. One you "draw" magic from a couple of places. You can also "draw" from special points that refresh every so often to aquire more. You can "draw" from mobs as well. Now you can use these spells in battle which is fine
date: but let me say this game isn't really about magic as the other Final Fantasys. If there was a "grind" in the game its from drawing magic to aquire enough of it. So what is the point of magic if you don't really want to use them against mobs? Well as I was saying earlier
recommended: FF8 uses a "Junction System". This allows you to "Junction" magic to your main attributes. Your Hp
hoursPlayed: Mp
voteText: Att
helpfulPercent: etc. Doing this augments your abilites and makes you pretty damn strong. This is also how you overcome the level scaling to make your character stronger. You can level up but remember
votesHelpful: mobs scale with you so this allows you to overcome this "handicap". If there is a "grind" in FF8
votesTotal: this is it. Which if you ask me
votesFunny: its far better "drawing" for magic than spending more time to grind for EXP for hours on end. I also told you that you could beat the game at the starting level. Which sounds bad but honestly beating the game at a lower level is way easier than a high level. Using the Final Battle as a reference
commentsCount: without spoiling
column16: beating it at a low level was hard but certianly not difficult. But i will say beating it at max level was one of the most challenging battles I have ever done in a game before. It took me close to 2 hours to beat that battle. With the active battle and max level I was on the edge of my seat the whole time. Note that it took me many of times to even succeed in doing this. It was simply a rewarding feat to acomplish. I can also atest to this being the hardest boss I have fought from any of the other Final Fantasy titles.\n\nSome tweaks have been done to the actual battle system. The main charactor uses a weapon called a gunblade. In battle you can attack like you normally would with no problems. But it has another feature that allows for it to do more damage. If you press a certain button at the precise time
column17: you will pull the trigger and shoot as you attack. This effectively adds more damage to your normal attack. It uses a turn base battle system that is active
column18: which means you have to think fast on your feet. No planning your attack like chess for the best move
column19: you have to be quick and do something or just keep getting attacked over and over. Some might see that as a turn off which I can understand just be aware its there. Summons are back in this game as well. They will be mighty helpful. They also learn abilites as well. Most noteworthy is the "boost" ablity. This allows you to push a button repeatedly to amplifiy the damage done. Its a nice to be able to do that but after the bazillionth time it will get old. Still to this day I would have like to have a final ablitiy to just do max damage without that button mashing marathon. Also the animations for the summons are top notch for its time. Truely amazing but some are really long and overdone
column20: would have been nice to be able to skip them. Annoying yes
column21: dealbreaker no.\n\nProbaly the most agreeable positive about FF8 is its included "card game". Triple Traid is its name and it is crazy fun that I am suprised was never given its own game. It sorta starts out slow but as you collect more cards you really start being sucked into it grasp. I personally have logged into FF8 just to play the card game and nothing else. So simple
column22: but yet so much depth and strategy. Traveling to new areas brings about new rules to the game. Some of these rules are good and some downright brutal. Also there are "rare" cards to win from certain people. Some you might only have one chance to aquire so maybe using a guide isn't a bad idea in this area.\n\nTo talk about the story would ruin alot of it. I won't mention it but I'll hit on a few high points. I kinda throws you right into the middle of everything and you'll feel like you understand what's going on. Then you'll go from knowing what going on to not having the slighest clue. That formula happens multiple times in this game. But each time it happens the story gets deeper and more seems to be happening. It gets dangerously close to being to long. When I first played this on the Playstation 1
column23: I was  wondering what was on disk 4 for the longest time. Even when I was at the end of disk 3 I felt like I had done so much I couldn't believe there was still a whole other disk to run though. Although in hindsight
column24: disk 4 felt almost out of place and to this day I still believe it was only that way because the amount of data on a cd-rom wasn't enough to do it the way it should have been. I works but only like hitting a foul ball 1 foot away from being a home run.\n\nOther worthy mentions are the locations. The cities are big and give a feeling of being alive. The music sets a nice tone to the atmosphere. Still some of my favorite music in the series
column25: not that any really stand out but they fit the games vibe. They are rendered backgrounds but still beautiful to look at. Throughout the world you can use roads to navigate around. You also gain access to cars to drive around the overworld. These greatly help speed up travel times. There are a few other ways of travel but I don't want to spoil any crazy details. Although I will say the "airship" in this game is the freaking best of all the FF games.\n\nWhat else is there in FF8? Quite a bit more if you ask me. For one it feels more like a world than past Final Fantasy titles. Or maybe I should say a little more grown up. This game as a whole seems more mature. But its overall experiance that makes it shine. The story goes up and down. There are high points and low points. But you are doing yourself a disservice if you pass on this up. Final Fantasy 8 knows its not like the rest of the series and its proud of that fact. If you give it a chance
column26: you might be pleastantly surprised that you wished played it sooner."

reviewText:
Short version: 90%Final Fantasy VIII was the point where the series reached a whole new level, thanks to small changes like the focus on the romantic story elements and the more realistic character design. The Steam edition includes a few additional features over the old PC release, making it one of the best ports of the game so far, recommended for old fans or newcomers who would like to experience one of the gems of the golden age of Final Fantasy.

Long version:Final Fantasy VIII was sort of a trailblazer when it came out. This was the first Final Fantasy game where we said goodbye to the traditional NES/SNES era cartoonish characters in favour of a more realistic design, and where the romance plot-- which is normally a secondary or tertiary storyline in similar games-- is promoted to be in the focus.
This won’t turn FFVIII into a romance/dating game, far from it: your main task is still to save the world/universe from the ridiculous-haired main villain. To do so you’ll have to gather friends and allies, explore much of the planet, and of course slowly discover a rich backstory told in two separate timelines, which will eventually (with a little guess work) uncover one of the most confusing, yet best-written stories of the genre.

Gameplay-wise FFVIII is a bit of an odd one out in the series with the large amount of gameplay changes it features. Although a lot could be said about these, the length of a Steam review simply cannot hold this much information, so let’s just say that some of them, like the expanded Limit Breaks, are favourably looked upon and work well; while others, like the junction system, were met with great opposition and never returned in later games.

The Steam version can be considered a well enough port of the original PlayStation release, with a bunch of really nice technical features, including better display compatibility and more user-friendly controlling. Sadly, like the Steam version of Final Fantasy VII, it features a subpar version of the original PSX music tracks, the same ones that were used in the original PC version.

Overall, the Steam Edition is Final Fantasy VIII may not be the HD remake lot of people still want, but it is a good port of an excellent game, well worth of owning and playing, even if you have the original PSX disc somewhere.

reviewText:
It's always fun taking a trip down memory lane. Already owning a copy of FF8 for the PS1, I know how well the game should play out. As per usual playing this on a different platform doesn't always result in better performance.

Soon as I dive into FF8 I notice the audio is unbelievably sub par for even the PS1's FF8 version. The music isn't anywhere near the same quality as it was on the PS1, it still sounds more midi then orchestral. Some SFX are even buggy! For example: The SFX for summoning Quetzalcoatl isn't even the correct one, you notice the sound is off because the SFX playing for Quetzalcoatl is actually the SFX that's supposed to be used for Phoenix Pinion.

The 90's trend of pre-rendered 3D backgrounds is back and have not been improved so expect alot of jaggy edges. The cinimatics still look quite the same but at least seem to have been improved to look nice, although the trailer looks much nicer, the ingame isn't quite the same.

Granted as I'm writing this I have only been as far as just recently beating Ifrit. After finding minor inconsistencies I'm quite afraid I'll find more broken things along the path.

This game isn't without its positives, you do have the full game so the hassle of changing discs is out the window. The player models have been significantly improved making them look much sharper. The game comes with steam achievments. It also comes with magic boost, what this does is it gives all your current characters have automatically obtained predefined magic stocks to their inventory. This ability can be used on any save file as many times as you want.

Also packaged in this release is Chocobo World so If you had that PS1 copy of FF8 and had only herd about Chocobo World and never had a chance to play it, then here it is.

Althought I may sound harsh towards this I still loved playing this or obviously I wouldn't have given it a thumbs up. It's great to be able to play this game once again.

To be clear, this is more of a re-release so don't expect it to be full HD.

reviewText:
Story – 1/5 -> 20%

The story is the typical “defeat the evil mastermind who threatens the life of the entire planet” type of story.  However, it is also incredibly convoluted and filled with many plot holes.  If you finished listening to some NPC's explanation about what is going on and still have no clue who's side they are on, then the story is too convoluted for its own good.  The one redeeming quality is that the main characters are well-defined.  You could easily identify with the main character, Squall.

Graphics – 4/5 -> 80%

The graphics are much improved over the horrible graphics of the previous game.  Some parts of the game still have rough edges, like a few of the character models, but for the most part, you shouldn't really notice any problems (at least for graphics of its time).  In particular, the FMVs look spectacular and flow smoothly with the rest of the game.

Sound – 5/5 -> 100%

None of the music or sound effects felt out of place.  Of particular note is the boss theme music which provided an appropriate adrenaline rush.

Controls – 9/10 -> 90%

Even if you have a problem with the default controls, it is possible to redefine them, and none of the extra ways the main controls were used for “minigames” felt awkward or misused.  The only problem I experienced was that the overworld was incredibly disorienting to navigate without the map open.

Resources – 5/5 -> 100%

Unlike the Playstation version, this version of FFVIII comes with Chocobo World without the need for a Pocketstation.  This provides an extra source for items beyond the main game.  Even if you choose not to abuse Chocobo World, FFVIII provides plenty of ways to keep your stats in tip-top shape.

One interesting resource system in this game is the SeeD rank.  Depending on your rank, you will be paid a certain amount as you walk around the world.  The higher your rank, the more you are paid.  There are a variety of ways to increase your rank, including monster kills and several sidequests.  This ensures you don't have to always face monsters to grind for gold if you don't want to.

Player Growth – 3/5 -> 60%

FFVIII's unique system is the Junctioning system.  Summon spirits are called Guardian Forces, or GF, which can be linked to particular characters to give them new abilities.  GFs can be taught new abilities for your characters to use as well as slots for particular stats in order to boost them with magic.

In addition, enemies level with you, in order to attempt to balance the game.  However, the game is not very well balanced for both newcomers and veterans alike, as leveling up too much tends to make the game more difficult, and it is possible to obtain late game magic spells at the beginning in order to boost your stats ridiculously high.

Learnability – 4/5 -> 80%

The game regularly provides the option to view a tutorial on various game mechanics.  Unfortunately, it can be rather invasive when you are given a chance later in the game to view a tutorial of a concept you have already been taught.

One feature of note is the SeeD Test.  In addition to increasing your SeeD rank, tests also provide a way to test your knowledge of the game mechanics.  The tests can prove to be a nice refresher if you forget anything, since you can view them at any time.

Difficulty - 12/15 -> 80%

The game initially provides a nice blend of challenging gameplay.  However, it does not provide enough challenging end-game content.  There is a super boss, but it is easy to defeat compared to other Final Fantasy games with super bosses.

Entertainment – 38/40 -> 95%

While the game is not very challenging overall, the Junction system still makes the gameplay very enjoyable.

Replay value – 3/5 -> 60%

As with most single player games, there is not much incentive to play the game again, especially if the story hurts your head.  However, the Junction system provides many different ways to approach boss fights.  It can be interesting to experiment with different approaches and create your own challenge runs.

Total – 84/100 -> 84%

I would recommend at least giving the game a try if you have never played this game before on the Playstation.  It is very fun to experiment with the Junction system and different magic spells.  If you have played the Playstation version and you are a completionist, you might still want to buy the PC version for the inclusion of Chocobo World.

reviewText:
People who have been rating this down because of the music don't care about the game. As a matter of fact, if they're letting some sub-standard music get in the way of the game, they probably don't even like the game to begin with and should be disregarded entirely.

First of all: the music isn't that bad. It's not bad at all, in fact, and certainly not enough to make people NOT reccomend the game. It has a retro feel to it, which, for any other game, people would be ♥♥♥♥♥♥ing over because #RETROISAWESOMELOL.

Second of all: yes, there is a second layer of DRM. Squeenix's login thing. I haven't had issues with my internet in long enough to accurately remember whether or not you actually NEED a constant stable connection, but I seem to recall that with FF7, you could play offline just fine as long as you had an account, which isn't difficult to create (and fake, if you so desire).

The game itself remains one of Final Fantasy's most underrated titles. People ♥♥♥♥♥ed about the need to grind" magic for the "unintuitive" junction system
date: but how is it any worse than grinding hundreds of millions of XP in any other title? I find the Junction system is laid out very simply and is easy-to-use. But then
recommended: I have at least two functioning brain cells to fire neural impulses between
hoursPlayed: so it wouldn't have taken me much effort to figure out even if I didn't understand it at first.\n\nThe characters are deep and relatable
voteText: to an extent (I mean
helpfulPercent: how well can you actually relate to a bunch of teenagers who were riased to be elite mercenaries during their childhood). The story is engaging
votesHelpful: if somewhat generic
votesTotal: but they genuinely tried to mix it up. The love interest plot developes naturally
votesFunny: though it gets somewhat rushed at one point late in the game when Female Love Interest (tm) goes into a coma and Male Love Interest (tm) who had previously been pushing her away constantly suddenly and abruptly realizes how much he needs her. Overall
commentsCount: it's a very good game. I look forward to when Squeenix releases FF9 for the PC *coughcough*hinthint*cough*getonityoulosers*cough*."

reviewText:
My personal favorite of all  Final Fantasy  franchises. Played this in 1999 with my brother when I was around 7! If you never played this game, you wouldn't believe how rich the story was, and how wide the range of the conflicts really are. Game is set in the future, but somehow post-apocalyptic after what happened in Centra around 4000 years ago, a Lunar Cry, where in current time people rebuild Centra into what is called a Garden. Relationships in this game are two of the most contributing factors, while others include politics, war, sorcery, and just massive destructions.

The game's background arts look ethereally.. poetic. It is just simply stunning. They're all 3D environment, just rendered into 2D and made it into a background where the 3D low-poly (characters) move accross the 3D space that have been motion-tracked to the background. The designs are mostly steampunk (architectural elements of Greek and French) combined with futuristic elements (try to observe the 3D models, colors, sounds, and advanced technology in the game).

Best battle system of all time. Indescribably cool. Junctioning GFs and Magic, draw, limit breaks, elements, statuses, real-time turnbased, weapon forging, student exams, and tons of other stuff. Just get the game and play it. And play its card-game, it's fun as hell.

reviewText:
I love this FF, I probably got over 9000 hours played across dozens of playthroughs... but this is such a low effort port cash-in I really can't recommend it.

Every single time you launch the game it pops up a keyboard controls box despite the fact that you're playing with a controller, so you have to press X on the keyboard to close it just to be able to use the controller to play. Then the resolution, despite having it set to 1920x1080 @ 144hz in the launcher, it runs in 4:3 aspect ratio with black side bars @ 30fps while roaming around the world and only 15.5fps during battles. How can it possibly get any worse you ask? With HIDEOUSLY pixelated 2D backgrounds and choppy ♥♥♥ looking 3D environment where you actually see the polygons sticking out, that's how.

Whatever.../10

reviewText: This is the same thing as the PC version much like FF7 on steam, but the main difference is this time around the PC version of FF8 is better than the PS1 version. The tecture quality is better for in battle effects like drawing magic, and areas are no longer fuzzy. Also the PC version came with Chocobo World! Which the steam version also has. Chocobo World is this cute little 8 bit game that uses mostly FF7 music and your chocobo auto battles enemies, when winning a fight a 3x3 grid shows up and a random spot in that grid fills in. Keep killing enemies until you fill out a row and you level up. Find your Cactaur friend in game and he gives you items you obtain in FF8 at the chocobo forest. Id recommend this even if the price seems a couple bucks too much.

reviewText:
I highly recommend FF8 to any gamer old or new.

The game came out for the PS one in 1999 and I do not think there is a game I have put more hours into. I know I have played through this game at least 3 times for the original PS version. I did lots of grinding to get all the items and collectables and I spent well over 400 hours on the PS one version.

The graphics were top of the line for its age and the gameplay (although much easier than other Final Fantasy games) has amazing playability with lots of in game collectables. The steam achievements are a nice addition to the game because it allows the player (especially new ones) to gauge their progress in the game. I personally already have them all and it took me about 100 hours to do it (again, I already bet the game multiple times and know all the secrets).

This is personally my all time favorite game due to having:
*Great story line (good plot points with lots of inside jokes)
*Amazing cut scenes
*LOTS of playability
*The best mini-game ever  (Triple Triad card game) (that's my opinion)
*Simple design character builds  (Positive and Negative - I would have liked to have had the ability to equip different types of armor to my characters for customized builds and appearance, but with the magic junctioning system it would have made the game mechanics A LOT more complicated)

I highly recommend this game. By far my favorite game to date.

reviewText:
Truly the best Final Fantasy. 7 was great, but my opinion changed after horrible additions to the story, prequels and movies and such: Cloud never changes and stays mopey. 9 was just horrible, the protagonist being a cross between David Bowie, Meg Ryan and a monkey. With FF8, you have a somewhat unlikeable punk kid protagonist that, through the 4 discs of the game, developes and starts becoming a man.

FF8 had the least amount of plot twists I feel. You have the main goal through most of the game: Kill the Sorceress!
8 has an awesome love story, a very likeable cast of characters, and amazing graphics for its time. I still get goosebumps watching the intro scene.

There's some definite flaws with this port, but this will probably always be my favorite of the series and my favorite childhood game as well. I read a review earlier recommending this to younger audiences, couldn't agree more. Let this game be etched in your memory from an early age, this is a true classic

reviewText: Not a remake but a simple port... but it is the one FF that should be remade. Not because it was great... just because it's so crappy that it's in deep need and hidden somewhere under the battles that take forever and game play that's complicated(not in a good way) there's probably a salvagable game. The pre-rendered background graphics really show their age in this port. they seriously couldn't have 2xSaI'ed them, really? . The junctioning system was crap when it came out on the PSX.. it's why they bothered to add a save-game mod to max out your spells. Almost everything about this game needs as big of an overhaul as FFXIV needed when it first came out. If you want to see outdated graphics with game play mechanics that you can play the whole game and never feel like you properly mastered them.. then give this game a try. The most immediate things that they could do to enhance this game is to replace the godaweful sound and prerendered back grounds and other simple things like turning the globe on the overworld... into an actual sphere rather than the bunch of polygons that passed for a sphere on the PSX.

reviewText:
i would not recommend this, the issues that existed with the original 2000 release version are still present, and square has not announced any kind of fix on the way.

Audio quality by default is just Knives and rusty nails in the form of sound produced from your speakers, without adaptation to modern sound synthisizers the game looks for things that dont exist and when it doesnt find these it goes back on its default software. so you could have an amazing Sound card from Creative Labs, wont change a thing.

no updated graphics and in some cases, poorer graphics. its the modern age, we expect a little more out of old releases, the minimum is it looks 100% like the original. but when you lose quality due to bad porting? thats just asking for 100k angry letters.

overall this is not worth it. i'd buy it for a dollar but i doubt it'll go on sale that big.

reviewText:
[Note that the following evaluation only applies to the Steam version of FF8]

In its present condition, I can't recommend this game, and even more If you have in mind your old PS1 version of FF8.

The Steam version is far inferior than the ancient one and you'll need to apply a couple of mods only to restore your childhood memories. Basically, there are two serious issues related to this version: the OST which is - I ought to say - awful, and the  background graphics which are blurred at best.

In sum, you'll pay 12 bucks to have an ersatz of your good and old Final Fantasy game. Then you'll spend 2 hours for the game to regain its former quality. Otherwise, you'll restart your PS1 like in the old days...

reviewText:
Was excited to play 8 again so I bought it, made it through one random fight and then stopped playing because the music sounded terrible. Square, you need to realize that the music in your games pre-voice acting was what helped convey emotions of the characters. As such players are emotionally attatched to the songs as well, and when the music doesn't sound right, you're butchering the game.

Fix the music. Now.

*Editing this review to say that I've since managed to play through almost the entire game, but still cringe every time I hear one of my favorite songs in such poor quality. I'll gladly change my review completely if the music is ever fixed, but until then...

reviewText: I played this game on the Playstation back when it came out and decided to buy the Steam version for old times' sake. Sorry to say that the PC port of this game is absolutely horrendous. It's not worth the purchase even on a deep discount.\nThe foremost problem is the controls: the button/key labels in-game are indicated using B1, B2, ... B10. Sure, you get shown the button meanings when the game boots, but it's not very useful when you can't remember the key combination for 'escape from battle' (required for the plot in the first game mission) and the in-game comments are useless. Also, don't bother with the controller support for this game. I attempted to use my wired 360 controller and found that the left and right triggers and the directional pad aren't detected -- you can't specify them in the custom configuration screen. (Also, there goes Zell's limit break.) On an aesthetic note, you should probably just mute the game instead of trying to tolerate the lo-fi, MIDI quality music. It's a shame, because the Dollet music mission is one of my favorites. Also, 'Magic Boost'? Seriously? Drawing magic was a HORRENDOUS idea to begin with, but Magic Boost is pretty much game breaking if you use it early on (it gives you 100 of the fire/thunder/blizzard, fira/blizzara/thundara, firaga/blizzaga/thundaga, all the status effect spells, and a few others... but fortunately it doesn't give you 100 of the top-tier spells like ultima, aura, etc) The game wasn't hard, there's no need for this kind of cheat.
