reviewText:
Most of the people here seem to give their thumbs up because of nostalgia.

I never played this game before, i never owned a console,
so I am rather unprejudiced. I played FF 7 some time ago and actually liked it.

FINAL FANTASY VIII plays very much like an interactive novel. While it is technically an open world game, this world is pretty much empty aside from the storyline. If you know that something like that will bother you, there is no reason to read on.

You will only like this game, if you like its story:
At the beginning of the game you are a young elite mercenary, who is just about to finish his final tests to become a full fledged member. This guy is antisozial, lacks understanding of his own emotions and has trust issues. The story is pretty much a coming of age story, with topics like taking on responsibility, friendship, first love, etc.. I would say the story is mostly aimed at 12 - 15 year olds. While it is certainly not an award-winning story it is not too bad either and it is always hard to treat those topics without getting too cheesy.

I actually like the graphics and have the impression that the game aged pretty well. Sadly the port is not well made. If you decide to pick it up, i would advice you to get the roses and wine mod. This mod introduces better music and volume control for the music. And you will absolutley want this volume control after a few hours X).

Now we come to the gameplay (running around and fighting) which is simple no fun. I will not go into detail. I am sure that this has already been discussed in great detail aka with much swearing" somewhere else.

I felt pretty OP from the start. The battle system is laborious
date: while not being complex. This is the biggest game design sin for me. It's a little bit like the game gives you a hundred buttons you can use and a big red one that says press me. Why press all the other buttons if the big one does the trick. The draw system makes this game extremly grindheavy and slow paced.\n\nWhat actually really infuriated me during gamplay was the way the game spams you with absolutly powerless and meaningless enemies. I would say 90% of all battles fall under this categorie. In the most extreme cases the enemies are so weak
recommended: that you could let the battle go one for 20 mins without doing anything and still win. If you played pokemon just imagine a game that constantly nags you with fighting safcons. This
hoursPlayed: combined with the fact that you often run around aimlessly
voteText: can aggravate even the most patient person. (I think the only reason why these enemies do exist is as refueling stations. Yes you actually heal yourself up by fighting them.)\n\nThe last thing I have to say about this game is
helpfulPercent: that it does a pretty bad job at communicating what you can interact with. While I expect that some people will call this exploration
votesHelpful: I think people should not have to go around clicking at and bumping into things in their spare time. This behavior is normally reserved to insects (flys and windows).\n\nI played this game only till the end of disc 2
votesTotal: so everything i wrote here does not inlclude the following chapters. All the issues i described here were present from minute one. I only played so far because i thought the game might get better at later stages. It did not up to that point.\n\nI can understand everyone that likes the game. The presentation is pretty much spot on
votesFunny: the gf animations are pretty cool and the story is not bad either. But the actuall gameplay isn't even mediocre. For me gameplay trumps everything else
commentsCount:
so i give this game a thumbs down.






"

reviewText:
inb4 fanboys mark this review as unhelpful because I didn't give it a 10/10.

Bear in mind that I am reviewing this game from the 2015 point of view, having not played it back in its day, and I have zero nostalgia for it.

Giving a review for this game is extremely difficult. It has a lot of interesting systems that make it one of the most interesting Final Fantasy games in the series. On the other hand, everything that is good and interesting about the game is opposed by a nearly equal ammount of convoluted or just plain terrible design decisions that will frustrate a modern player to no end. Some of this stuff may have been able to fly on the PS1 back in 1999, but in 2015, this stuff can grate your nerves. So let me try to point out the good and bad.

DRAW SYSTEM - THE GOOD: The draw system refers to the fact that characters don't have personal magic on them at all times. Instead, magic is reduced to consummable items (e.g. to cast Blizzaga, you will need to use 1 blizzaga item). To get more spell items, you have to draw" them (i.e. steal them) from enemies. The number you get is random. Sometimes you get zero or one
date: but a lot of times you'll get 5 or 6 at once. Each enemy has a menu of spells you can steal from. More useful and powerful spells can only be stolen from mini-bosses
hoursPlayed: and rare enemies. Once you've stolen the spell items
voteText: you can use them in combat or you can fuse them to specific stats to boost a character's parameters
helpfulPercent: like boosting fire def
votesHelpful: or adding fire to their attack
votesTotal: or increasing HP or vitality
votesFunny: etc. You have the option to either steal the enemy's spell (add it to your inventory) which just gives you the item and ends your turn
commentsCount: or you can cast the enemy's own spell at the enemy party immediately.\n\nDRAW SYSTEM - THE BAD: As much as all of the above is interesting
column16: you may find it frustrating that spells are essentially just items. You may also find it frustrating that
column17: in order to stock up on specific spells (especially more rare ones)
column18: you just waste a lot of turns usings your characters to steal
column19: steal
column20: steal
column21: etc etc 100 times. Stealing the spells is primarily useful for boosting parameters. The guardians (who we'll discuss in a moment) are so powerful that actually using the spells in combat is only sometimes---but rarely---useful.\n\nGUARDIAN SYSTEM - THE GOOD: The game calls them "guardian forces" for some reason
column22: but let's call them what they really are: summons. So this game decides to make summons front and center. You collect new summons as you go through the game
column23: which can be assigned to any character. Every summon has its one powerful spell it can cast
column24: but if you grow each summon (like a pokemon!) it can become more powerful
column25: boost the parameters of the ally using it
column27: or allow the user to summon it into battle more quickly. The summons are powerful
column28: and you will want to use them a lot.\n\nGUARDIAN SYSTEM - THE BAD: The summons are so powerful that you will want to use them almost exclusively. Physical attacks and magic attacks are
column30: so pathetic compared to summoning that you will only end up using physical/magic attacks "just for fun"
column31: or in the rare circumstances when you need to beat some enemy's gimmick. (basic attacks get better over time
column32: but do you really want to wait 60 hours for them to get better?) What about elemental weaknesses? Yeah
column34: but if its a choice between casting firaga or summoning Ifrit on them
column35: what are you going to do? You'll spam Ifrit. Managing the guardian forces is also laborious. It's about as exciting as meticulously shifting all of your materia gems around in FF7
column36: only it involves an even more convoluted system of sub-screens
column38: and even sub-sub-sub-screens. If I were new to RPGs
column39: I would have quit this game out of frustration just on account of its dogpiled menus. Also
column40: even though the game has TONS of summons to find
column41: you will absolutely miss the vast majority of them unless someone tells you in advance that most of them can only be stolen from bosses (via the "draw" command) or under special circumstances. You essentially need a strategy guide opened up as you play
column42: if you don't wanna miss a ton of them. Also
column43: the summon animations are sooo long. They are painfully long. And since they are the focus of the game
column44: you have to sit dumbly and watch them a lot. This is slightly improved when they level up enough to learn "boost"
column45: which allows you to play a button tapping mini-game to pass the time during the animation and raise the attack power of the summon
column46: but 1) you'll have to check a strategy guide to learn how boost works
column47: because the game can't be arsed to explain it; 2) they are sooo long though.\n\nCHARACTERS - GOOD: In-game character models look much better than the dopey FF7 ones
column48: although their faces do look kinda pinched and weird. Squall always looks cross-eyed
column49: but I accept that because it amuses me. The characters and story get more attention and are overall more appealing than FF7 in my opinion.\n\nCHARACTERS - BAD: A lot of cliche (but that's typical of JRPGs). Squall is a stereotypical angsty and brooding I-hate-everything-and-have-a-bad-attitude-leave-me-alone-and-get-out-of-my-room emo teenage boy type. At least at first. As a teenage boy I would have thought he was the coolest. As a grown man
column50: I find him immature and irritating. He gets better. Oh
column51: and as much as other FF8 fans have told me they like the segments
column52: you also will have your game and story progress continually interrupted by a "Biggs and Wedge" sequence
column53: where you have to play through a complete dungeon and story sequence as some characters you don't know. After you play a lot of them
column54: they will start to tie into the main story more and make more sense
column55: but for a long time they are complete non-sequiturs. Who are these people? Why do I care? Can this just be over so I can go back to Squall and friends? What is the point of this? Maybe you'll dig it
column56: but these felt like disruptions (or interruptions) to me
column57: so I didn't care for them.\n\nOTHER - BAD: Convoluted menus. Fails to explain some game features completely or gives very poor explanations of other features (there is a tutorial/guide available
column58: but its helpfulness varies). While the draw/guardian (aka steal/summon) systems are interesting in a lot of out-of-combat ways
column59: they also make the inside-combat part of the game feel lopsided and weird. Plus they require an inordinate amount of fiddling in menus---as bad as fiddling with materia gems or worse (but
column61: some people love all of that fiddling
column63: have fun). The game also some very bad dungeons in it
column64: such as one dungeon consisting of 15 copy-pasted floors of the exact same doughnut-shaped room you have to run completely around (i.e. poor design trick used to make you trip more random encounters while not caring enough to make the dungeon any more interesting). The game is also a completely clutz when it comes to save points. Don't be surprised if you are made to sit through 30-minutes of unskippable story sequences and then ambushed with a boss fight you had no way of knowing was coming. No saves. If you die or forget to steal the guardian force
column65: prepare to do that entire 30-minute boring story sequence again. This doesn't just happen once. It is a repeat problem. The game tends to suck at save point placement in general.\n\nSteam only allows thumbs up or thumbs down
column66: when what I'd like is a pair of shrugging shoulders that says "mixed feelings". You might like it! But for me personally
column70: and questionable or convoluted design choices just adds up to me banging my head against the wall a little bit too often. Like the world's cutest dog that also won't stop sh***ing on the floor
column71: it is a thing I feel compelled to love with all my heart but equally as often feel compelled to drop off on the side of the road."

reviewText:
Squall is a badass.  That being said, there are some tonal issues in this one.  It seems like they thought maybe with the once again widespread popularity of Final Fantasy (after the greatness of FF7) they should cater more to kids...so we have a band of mainly high school aged nutcases and very little real drama (and where's the blood?).

We watched Sephiroth slaughter an entire building of people in Final Fantasy 7 and stick a sword through Cloud's true love...here the most controversial element is that the main villain is married to the good guys' high school principal (which also just doesn't make sense).  And oh yeah, dumb spoiler alert...our heroes have all known each other since they were toddlers--but they all forgot!

They were on to something with Laguna hitting on the chick at the beginning but they totally dropped the ball with story after that.  And what is with Squall's shunning of Rinoa, my God.  She was dangling from that ledge for like an hour...  If Shinji from Evangelion got together with Squall you'd have two of the most emotionally confused individuals in Japanese popculture.  The forever wimp and the mother of all angsty yet shy dark horses.

The good?  Character design, some challenging battles, when Squall gets bulled by the jetpack-riding Galbadian soldier and they both fly out the emergency exit, Triple Triad, when Rinoa and Squall book it past a schoolyard full of soldiers and students throwing down, a few examples of gnarly music, once they reveal that Ultimecia jazz the story starts to pick up again...

reviewText:
Everybody knows how good this game is, great to see it coming to steam!

Only the music... same bad MIDI files... the music on the PS-One is a million times better. This should be adressed ASAP, so for the time being, I am not recommending this to anyone. The music of FFVIII was one of the things that captivated the players, and make a sweet taste of nostalgia for many. I surely recommend the game, but not in this form.

Also what is strange... the characters, Squall, Quistis etc. all seem more... sharper. Their graphic quality has actually improved, while the surroundings... are of a lesser graphic quality.

All in all, just a strange release! Some graphic elements improved, others lessened. Very bad quality music, which takes away the whole atmosphere and heart of the game. Adress it quickly is my advice.

reviewText:
Crashes a lot. Also summon animations take 30 seconds and are NOT skippable. Rough math here, but

every 2 summons = 1 minute
120 summons = 1 hour
1200 summons = 10 hours

I barely got to the first boss and it took 12 summons to kill him. That's 6 minutes of the same animations over and over and over.  BLAM turn around and have another boss fight, that takes 3 summons before it will let you leave, it chases you, 3 more summons, rince repeat about 5 times and you've summoned 15 times. That's 7 minutes of the same animation, over, and over, and over, and over. That's 13 minutes spent watching the same 3 summon animations.

That time builds up, gets old, and gets the game uninstalled. If you like watching the same thing over and over again, maybe you'll enjoy the game.

Waste of money.

reviewText:
The Goods
-Fantastic Story line
-Scaleable
-Just like the original game

Ah, my childhood.
I don't understand why the early final fantasy games keep making me want to play them over and over D:.
Either way. This port, sucks, just like the original. It seems only final fantasy 7 had a GOOD release port that seemed to not be virtually emulated through a cheap tactic of building a runtime for the game.
Its not as bad of a port as final fantasy 13. Though, there is a lot of things they could have changed to make it feel, like an actual PC version.

Over all, its a good game. but still, the game could be reworked to fit a PC custom more.

The Bads
-Completely original graphics: SURE, we have resolutions! but..I mean, this is awful. Some characters inworld are so blocky and hard to look at due to the significant upscaling thats taking place, and it gets much, much worse past 1080P (Deling city..LOL)
-Controls: This game screams controller. No ifs, no ands, no butts. The keyboard layout doesn't even work right unless you have a controller. Its a game thats really bad as a port.
-Need a Square Enix Account: This one is pretty self explanitory. Took a while to get that setup due to SE's slow network or, my email just is slow. either way, its another form of DRM really.
-Cloud saves: This game has cloud saves, however it is not as bad as FF13-2 or FF7's cloud saving. Saves are instant and straight forward, however I have had a few moments where the saves did not update on the cloud, and the previous cloud saves were used, resulting in a backtrack of storyline, which annoyed me greatly.
-Midi Music, Low quality video: Everything is upscaled or compressed in this game. Videos are not that great looking, and to be honest. I feel if i had the PSX version it would look, and play better
-Locked framerates: given, because of how the game was built. Both FF7 and 8 are like this.

reviewText: When it comes to Final Fantasy I often hear people complain about 8....in the ps era which consisted of Final Fantasy 7, 8, and 9, 8 was looked at as the black sheep. I feel like the style had to do heavily with this. The game has a bit more of a realistic feel than most, that is for everything..architecture, people design... It just feels a bit more realistic than any other, which shouldn't be a bad thing, but a lot seem to think so.... This game has the open world which after a certain point is free to explore in it's entirety....With so much to do, mini-games, secrets, and all sorts of cool things to come across...\n\nA great game for anybody who likes the Final Fantasy series.  i give it 9/10

reviewText:
One of the best games I've ever played. Reminds me of my childhood.  Epic story, interesting characters, more epic gameplay with lots of secrets and gorgeous cinematics & soundtrack. I just love it.

Disadvantages of PC version:
- Crappy music quality - It just can't be compared with PSX. If you're using a good headphones or speakers, it would torture your ears.
- Well, you may be surprised by the pixels :). Too bad, that Square didn't add some scaling to backgrounds (etc).
Nevertheless, the game is worth every penny. You may fix the sound & graphics by implementing some community mods - haven't fully tested it but I hope it won't be crashing my game.

reviewText: Quite possibly one of the greatest stories of all time. The artwork and CGI of the Final Fantasy games during the late 90's was some of the best displayed in a video game during that time. This game was confusing, surprising, and captivating from beginning to end. There are secrets around every corner, not quite as much as Final Fantasy VII, but even more so when you consider the content provided with the card system and spell system. Some complain that the spell system is confusing, but a simple google search for a guide or video explination will solve confusion issues these days. The graphics upgrade provided with the PC version is really only an upgrade of the 3d modeling in the game. Fight scenes look a bit cleaner but it is clearly apparent that no improvement was made in regards to textures or higher texture sampling for the higher resolution options. This actually creates a very ugly full screen appearance when traveling through areas in towns. I am completely confused at Japan's approach to PC remakes of their console games. The lack of video options and the requirement for a launcher brings me back to 1998 when I was playing 'Redneck Rampage' on my Pentium III. If you really MUST have this game for PC like me, or if you insist on experiencing this game for the story, get it. Otherwise skip it.

reviewText:
I have a strange relationship with this game.

The junction system is amazing; its QTE scenes drive me up a wall. I fell in love with the characters, when they weren't being bland obnoxious plot devices. Its story is grand and beautiful; the romance can choke a horse. It is the game that sparked my passion for storytelling; it is a game that rouses my passion for critique.

This was the first Final Fantasy I played (I would later find it difficult to get into its predecessor). While VII's opening scene was mysterious and atmospheric, you could feel here in VIII how personal the story set out to be, even though you knew nothing about these two men or what their beef with one another was about. At the moment, it didn't matter--- you felt immersed in characters who each wanted something badly enough to entertain the hell out of us to get it.

The graphics in the cut scenes and environments were cutting edge, barely manageable on the original Playstation console (for those unaware, the original copy of the game was laid out on four beautifully covered compact discs). They were employed conservatively, providing emotion through character's facial expressions at the right moments, even though no voice acting was ever used. This brought the characters to life in a way I hadn't seen before. And being a dumb kid (I was eleven), these kinds of visuals helped my imagination stir. Manipulative? If you think so, I won't get you started on the music, another element applied with deadly precision to suck me deeper into this world.

The story centered around people young enough to be in school but old enough for me to look up to. It opens gently and welcoming with a local, homey sort of feel. You're on a small island with your school on one side and a cozy little town on the other. Some forest, a little cave with fiery monsters but you don't have to go there yet, a beach and the loveliest music from the streets of Balamb to the halls of Balamb Garden. Even the world map's score injects the mystery of exploration into the experience.

Pages of gameplay exposition nobody wants to read and everybody skips is clumsily slapped on in globs at several points when it should have been woven into the exploration that the atmosphere demanded. Setting the first quest on a timer was also uncharacteristically uninviting (especially for a younger kid--- I always hated timers, no matter how forgiving, which to be fair, this really was).

The story kicks off with a battle that's sort of explained but not really. All you know is that you're being dropped into a city-state that's fighting occupation from the neighboring empire.

This is where my main criticism of the game begins.

One can argue that a younger guy (the protagonist is 17) is not going to be well-versed in politics or little skirmishes waging on the other side of the world. But Squall doesn't seem to know a thing about the world he's studying to protect. It's like he beamed in right before the start of the game. I think a lot of my confusion could have been assuaged had my main character some intellectual binding to the world in which he grew up. He's always expressing himself to the audience in thought, which was a good way of developing his outlook on things from one situation to the next--- subtle hints on his opinions concerning the expansive Galbadian Empire would have provided some desperately-needed grounding. It's not a very big world--- two superpowers and three sparsely-populated independent continents which exist mostly for the side quests. A few cities. Maybe this was the game's way of highlighting the story's elements, but it seemed that all the key global events could be processed by the equivalent of a high school senior.

While it could be said that Squall knew all of these things, but didn't care enough to ruminate on them, some of the technical exposition leading up to the event could have been chopped down and garnished with the overall state of things. But then again, much of that would have been obvious to the people of this world. If it was only the opening mission that did this, maybe I could have blamed myself for not keeping up with the database, if there was such a thing pertaining to Galbadia's occupation of Dollet, but the story gets very complex very fast, and could have been tied up better (who the hell is Rinoa supposed to be again?)

Having said that, once you get a grip on things--- the complicated politics, different cultures, the relationships and histories of nations, the inception of Garden, the threat of the sorceress--- the world was fascinating and remarkably well constructed. If you play through several times, you will see how consistent and sensible everything is. It's like the writers had a brilliant tome detailing everything about this world and pulled only pieces from it to write the game. This is not inherently a bad thing, but in this case there needed to be more.

If such a tome exists, and I believe it does, it needs to be found. Because of all the entries in this franchise, it is the eighth installment which will benefit the most from not only a remake, but a reimagining.

That is why I love this game as much as I do: I see it for what it could have been. My imagination stole from it so much more than what was given.

The characters were so different from one another, their interactions felt alive (of course, this has almost always been the case with Final Fantasy). They were funny, they were annoying, they were scary, they were sympathetic or any combination of these. They had desires, likes and dislikes, dreams, ambitions, opinions (I would have liked some more gray in the moral compass though). There were some characters who needed work, and I think their overarching development of friendship could have been done better than filling in the empty spaces with that ham-fisted it turns out we all grew up together" subplot. Individual scenes were fleshed out well and the imagination is taken by the hand to do a lot of the work on its own

reviewText:
Outside of your scope of the Final Fantasy series as a whole, this game is awesome. People constantly complain about the music and.. It could be better. It is the original music, but it gets the job done all the same.

Most games i play, i tend to try not to take a guide to play it with me.. This game and FF7 are the exceptions. The game itself is huge and fun to play, although it does get repetitive after some time. There are secrets in the game which you cannot find until the very end of it, so its important to know where those are and how to access them, although they are not needed.

The leveling system in this game is unique. The creatures level with you. You can get to level 100, like the traditional Final Fantasy games allow, however you could also defeat the end boss @ level 20. It's like that. There is no need for grinding and will allow you to experience the story without need for the grind.

The story is great. Many say it doesn't make much sense, but thats because there are elements of it that you need to explore for yourself. Those elements will not reveal themselves to you, you need to search for them! Or use your guide.

Overall, i would recommend this game, if for nothing else, the nostalgia value it brings. Great game.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A moody unlikeable protagonist. A strained love story. Weak charicatured party members. And yet it's the Final Fantasy I've put the most time into (so far). The junction system is just too good; it deserves the hours you spend hunting monsters, making and collecting cards, refining items and magic, so at the end you are a literal dimension shifting kiling machine. The Triple Triad card game is just icing on the cake and so addictive, and Chocobo World is even a nice addition for picking up rare items. The ending does make everything worthwhile, and though at times I was left frustrated, ultimately this game was an excellent experience.

reviewText:
Warning: Review is not proofread, as I am a lazy human being.

Final Fantasy VIII is a somewhat underdog classic in the Final Fantasy franchise. It was controversial in it's release for being vastly different then any Final Fantasy, or for that matter, RPG on the Playstation platform. Though critically acclaimed, alot of fans felt that the game derived too far from it's traditional JRPG roots. This is somewhat of a comical criticism in comparision to modern Final Fantasys, but at the time, the game had a shocking effect primarily for it's less cartoonish appearance, it's different take on equipment and item systems, and of course, who can forget the controversial junction system. The story as well, recieved much criticism for being overly melodramatic and at times feeling complete. The characters can come across as quite hokey at times as well.

All this to say, that this is probably my favorite Final Fantasy game. I played it shortly after finishing FFVII, and while I do echo the esteem afforded to FFVII, FFVIII reached me in a way that game failed to. I found at the time, I could relate very much to the game's main protagonist Squall and his journey to venture outside of himself and into this bigger world of responsiblity. In a sense, it was a story for me as an adolescent, trying to make sense of love and the world. Sure, it does have a bit of a hokey love story element, but the thing that gripped me the most about this game was Squall's inner mental dialogue, and of course the unforgettable world in which the game takes place. I have to say it, I love the world of FF8. It is very much less steampunk and more sci fi, but its full of beautiful villages and vistas, and the people who inhabit this world are interesting. The story may feel uneven, but there was definite intention here to bring a lively world that spoke more then what the actual plot could, and I love the plot. The music is written by FF veteren Nobuo Uematsu, and it is as expectedly incredible. Every song fits so well with the environment; Nobuo has a rare talent of telling a story within a story. More could be said about Nubuo, and much has, but for the sake of room and time, just take my word for it.

Concerning this version: this version of FF8 is wihin the same sort of rerelease as the FFVII rerelease. Keyword here is rerelease, NOT REMAKE. I can't emphasize that well enough. This is a RERELEASE. If you buy this game expecting a fully fledge HD remake, you will be disappointed, and you should be, because this is what SQUARE has made clear since the beginning. That said, for a rerelease this ain't bad considering that unlike FF7, the PC version of FF8 was considered somewhat inferior to the PS port. This was because at the time, the release was buggy and there were certain elements that made the game feel more like a port and less like a pc game. Much of that is retained in this version, but now we have the added benefit of actually being able to customize the game's graphics to your native resolution without the burden of modding. That is essentially what you are paying for here. The cinematics are fine, and cleaned up. The actual ing game graphics look nice, and you can see now clearly just how smooth this game was designed to run. The animations are much smoother this time around. Because of the clearer graphics however, you will notice some inconsistent fragments (pixelated people and backgrounds) that were not intended to be seen with a modern screen resolution. But I find this to be not a deal breaker. Also the music is sadly, the original chopped up midi from the pc release. Hopefully Square will patch in the glorious PS original score at some point.

So in summary, FF8 is a flawed but still great game and one of my personal favorites. If you are expecting something more then a release of a game that is more then 10 years old, you will be disappointed. If you are like me though, and have fond memories of the game from your childhood, then you may find yourself surprised just how well things translate.

reviewText:
Firstly, FFVIII is great and I love it. It's for that reason alone that this is playable.
Watch the video on the store page. The FMVs do NOT look anywhere near that good in game as the footage they've used is enhanced video that they chose not to put into the game for some reason.
Some of the textures have seen mild improvement over the PSX version however, they must have outsourced the job to EA as it is incredibly halfássed as can be seen in this screenshot.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=491167562
I mean just look at that contrast between Quistis and Cid. He's a 16-bit pixel sprite! And this is by no means an isolated incident. The game is full of sloppy work like this.
And then there's the controller support which frankly leaves a lot to be desired. All prompts are replaced with generic B1, B2, B3 prompts. Considering that no controller in existence labels its buttons this way you'll need to write down the corresponding PSX / XBOX configurations or you'll find things like Zell's limit break unusable.

That said, it's FF8 on PC. What other options do you have? Even though I looked after my PSX, it can't play my original FF8 discs without skipping/crashing when the FMVs play so yeah... it's playable, but Squeenix should be ashamed of themselves for doing this to a classic game.

Recommended but only for lack of a better option.

You used to be better than this, Squaresoft...

reviewText:
You probably heard about this game before, so I'll go into the details about this version first.

This is basically the PC port from 1999. That means it has poor quality midi music. I recommend installing the playstation music pack, which is provided in the guide section. You can turn on graphical enhancements, which I find awful. They mess up the textures so you see the geometry clipping or floating, which are seamless in the original version. You'll have achievements, too. They are a little uninspired and seem just mandatory for the most part.

You can't just start the game and lay back on your couch with your gamepad - like with big picture. You absolutly need to put in some keyboard commands first. I find this annoying at the beginning of every session. Also, the in-game button prompts don't use the Xbox (or psx) names and that's confusing. If you're told to quickly press the B3 button, you'll know why.

You have theoretically unlimited save files, which is nice. And you can play the built-in pocketstation game Chocobo World. That feature was useless in Europe back in the day, because the pocketstation was only released in Japan. But that minigame is not that good. For the most part it plays itself and you just have to hit enter every couple of minutes, so it continues. Now think about how long it takes to reach LV 99 there. That's just preposterous.

The game itself is highly unconventional, which can be curse or blessing. You can't deny it has top-notch production value and incredible presentation, thanks to the pre-rendered backgrounds. That's always Squeenix' strong point. The thing with changing the formular" is
date: that it feels like done for its own sake. Elements of typical jrpgs like character levels
hoursPlayed: magic
voteText: equipment and so forth don't have that much of a pay-off as if they were changed just for the hell of it. It is extremly complex and begs you to first familiarize with it. There is a lot of depth to the micro-management but it is overwhelming for a beginner. Plus
helpfulPercent: the menu interface is unappealing to look at
votesHelpful: though you spend a lot of time arranging your stuff. It is best you don't even start to wrap your head around the meaning of all of this or you'll go crazy how "gamey" and nonsensical the entire system is.\n\nOne thing I can't just easily criticize is the music. I know tastes are different and you can't just call it good or bad. But from a quality point of view I think the music is a little uninspired and underwritten. I get the role of these jazzy tunes in this more realistic universe. The composition uses much more natural sounding instruments and percussion
votesTotal: but it sounds way more flat and shallow than other works of Uematsu.\n\nI don't mind the card game. Not at all. Sometimes it's unpredictable and frustrating and it takes long to complete but for the most part I find it intriguing. If you don't
votesFunny: ignore it. You can just transform the cards you get without playing into items and will be fine.\n\nThen there's the drawing. You can finish the game with no problems without ever drawing magic. But I agree that it's initially counter-intuitive. Here's why. When you are introduced to this feature
commentsCount: you have nothing stocked yet the urge to be as good as possible. You can already see the ceiling. The more you have
column16: the better you are. The only thing standing in the way is your investment. You will have to have the dicipline to say "I may not be maxed out right now
column17: but eventually I will be. Let's move on for now!" Don't let it bug you. The game is balanced well enough.\n\nYou can be forgiving with the mechanics but I think we'll all agree that the story is the weakest part. It is just contrived and incoherent and it doesn't know where it's going with all its set pieces. Plus there are plot holes and deus ex machina which are a sign of poor and lazy writing. It is pretty cheesy and schmaltzy
column18: too.\n\nBottom line
column19: this is a real Frankenstein's monster. It is impressive
column20: elaborate and stuffy but still an abomination you're puzzled about it even lives. It has much love to give but will always be a manifestation of ambition gone wild."

reviewText: Massive fan of the Final Fantasy series, but never got round to this one. Played it as a kid and got a bit bored truth be told. I  much preferred 7. However, playing it now, i'm realising what I missed out on. I heard and saw good things so I gave it a try. I can say it was a very good purchase. Squall is still yet to grow on me, but i really like Zell and Selphie. I'm really looking forward to what's going to happen next and I can't stop playing it. Already on 5 hours tonight alone. The junction system with abilities is good, but i preferred 7 with it's materia system. However, it is fun to mess around with and I do like how summons work. The music is good, especially the boss theme, and feels like a true Final Fantasy of old. Overall, much better game than I was expecting. I had a bad first impression as a kid and never really gave it a chance, but I'm glad this time I did.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Great and deep story
- The graphics are not too shabby like the first release on the PC
- Vast world
- Many methods of transportation like cars to airships even though the world is mostly consisted of an archipelago
- Chocobo World
- Receives salary from Garden
- Amazing music
- Breathtaking scenery

Cons:
- Complex battle system compared to other Final Fantasy games
- The enemies are always on par with the party's level, making battles less challenging
- Every time we need to use magic, we need to Draw from enemies
- Item drops are hard to come by
- Battle items like potion are rarely used due to restorative magic can be obtained early in the game
- Not recommended for someone who's just started playing RPGs

Rating: 8/10

reviewText:
This is a tough one to review.

This game is one of my childhood most favorite game. I have finished it so many times I lost count years ago. So you can imagine how disappointed I was once my first cd of the original game got destroyed by accident.

This game still holds up quite well, graphics are better then they were in the original (though not as good as modern day games) and the music is not that bad either (could be better but I can live with it).

What brings me to the conclusion to not recomend this game is one fatal bug. A bug that seems to be connected with syncing achivements to the servers (which in my opinion are useless anyways). This bug describes itself as crashing the game. It can happen anywhere, in combat, between loading screens or just while walking on the field. This is especially bad when you do not have saving points anywhere you like and cannot save when you want and as often as you wish. This is such a drawback that I cannot recommend this game until this mayor bug has been fixed. MEanwhile I recommend playing Final Fantasy VII (7). This bug is not there even though there are achivements in that as well. I do not understand why but I just know that this bug is really annoying and kills the game..... for now.

I am too stubborn to give up because I want to finish this game again, I just love it that much, but for those who are curious as to wheather or not to try this game then you should wait until this bug has been fixed. THEN I will change this into positive review.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was psyched up when I saw this game on Steam, and after buying the re-release of FFVII direct from Square (whished I waited for the steam version though to be honest) I was thinking YES, VIII is re-released too this is going to be epic.

Now fans of the original PS version, may remember that this game supported analouge controls and the like, and it made the gameplay a lot smoother, however this version, no analouge support, the controls are a bit finiky if you ask me, you try to setup a control pad, but knowing what button is what half the time is annoying (even when using a XBOX controller for Windows) A little more work on the control scheme would have been nice, and for me, that is the thing that lets this down.

This has all the flaws from the original PC release back in 1998-1999, which is glitchy and dodgy controls, the only good thing about this release is the magic booster, allowing you to enjoy the epic story line a lot easier without having to draw masses of magic from a load of enemies.

Maybe only play it if you haven't played VIII before, but bare in mind the poor control method.

reviewText: There were always a few issues with this game, foremost being the magic system. In this current version for the PC the problem is mostly the controls put in place. Not only can't you customize your controls, as you can in most PC games, but the buttons you're forced to use are awkward at best. Add that to the fact that they only refurbished the graphics on select parts of the world and animations, the volume controls don't work, and the fact that you have to sign into a squareenix account on top of being logged into steam and you have a craptastic experience that is sure to annoy. Thanks Square, I'll make sure to ignore future titles in the steam store and go with a group that thinks about what the player expects and/or wants in their gaming experience.\n1 out of 5 folks.

reviewText:
I bought the Game about an hour ago.

The Download went fine, but when a Launcher came up requesting me to sign up a Squeenix Account the Horror started. I admit i didnt check a third party launcher was required to launch the Game.
The Launcher gave the Option to create an Account. Unfortunatly the Confirmation Email which was supposed to be sent to the Mail I chose didnt show up for about 15 Minutes. That started to worry me and therefore i tried it with another EMail.

If you're interested in what EMail I used, the first attempt had been a Google-Mail (Both Versions @gmail and @googlemail) and the second one was a @hotmail . Both end up in no response so i started up Google and looked for that issue.

It was already a known issue that Confirmation Mails arent sent. I then tried some advises by fellow People and in the end it took me longer to create an account than actual downloading the Game... thats really sad. The 1 Hour Gametime until now is nothing more than the Launcher being open in the Background while waiting for the Confirmation Email.


I will consider changing my review based on what issues might arise before the Game even launched.

If someone might stumble along the same Issue, this Link helped me:
https://secure.square-enix.com/account/app/svc/Login?cont=account&request=mogstation
Just follow the instruction up to the Point the Account is created and activated, everything else seems not necessary.

reviewText: Massive fan of the Final Fantasy series, but never got round to this one. Played it as a kid and got a bit bored truth be told. I  much preferred 7. However, playing it now, i'm realising what I missed out on. I heard and saw good things so I gave it a try. I can say it was a very good purchase. Squall is still yet to grow on me, but i really like Zell and Selphie. I'm really looking forward to what's going to happen next and I can't stop playing it. Already on 5 hours tonight alone. The junction system with abilities is good, but i preferred 7 with it's materia system. However, it is fun to mess around with and I do like how summons work. The music is good, especially the boss theme, and feels like a true Final Fantasy of old. Overall, much better game than I was expecting. I had a bad first impression as a kid and never really gave it a chance, but I'm glad this time I did.

reviewText:
One of my Favorite FF games, not as good as FF9 but I still enjoy it.

FF8 took a big risk with it's jump to computers back in the days and new graphical looks, how ever, the game remained true to the FF-series in terms of combat, story, music and so on.
There are a few sadly less well made parts of this game but for me, it's all acceptable and the game is still very much a genuine Final Fantasy aswell as RPG game.

8/10

reviewText:
I was psyched up when I saw this game on Steam, and after buying the re-release of FFVII direct from Square (whished I waited for the steam version though to be honest) I was thinking YES, VIII is re-released too this is going to be epic.

Now fans of the original PS version, may remember that this game supported analouge controls and the like, and it made the gameplay a lot smoother, however this version, no analouge support, the controls are a bit finiky if you ask me, you try to setup a control pad, but knowing what button is what half the time is annoying (even when using a XBOX controller for Windows) A little more work on the control scheme would have been nice, and for me, that is the thing that lets this down.

This has all the flaws from the original PC release back in 1998-1999, which is glitchy and dodgy controls, the only good thing about this release is the magic booster, allowing you to enjoy the epic story line a lot easier without having to draw masses of magic from a load of enemies.

Maybe only play it if you haven't played VIII before, but bare in mind the poor control method.

reviewText:
i feel like this is an often overlooked gem

a great game with more depth and a funnier story than ff7

the fact that you can beat the game without ever leveling once by using cards a magic junction system and an encounter no enemies except bosses ability is so refreshing

a solid quirky love story that deals with teenage angst ayn rand like selfishness and other emotional psychological issues in an odd but funny way

strays from grinding for levels to get stronger to kill the boss and places you in a more cerebral game

the replayability is high because the card mini game it comes with is so good even by itself without the rest of the game.

reviewText:
I wanna make one thing clear: I love Final Fantasy (and RPGs in general). I have played the heck out of FFs 1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10, and 14, and loved every one. I really, REALLY want to like 8. Square decided they wanted to do something different. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but it came crashing down in this instance.

Side note: Credit where it's due, this game has a great soundtrack. The boss theme and Man With the Machine Gun are just two tracks I enjoy having stuck in my head. Nobuo Uematsu has never disappointed.

Anyway. Lets go down the list of reasons this game doesn't want me to like it.

-The Draw system: Lets be fair; I was prepared to tolerate the draw system. Magic is a limited resource in all RPGs, and frankly, this seemed considerably less limiting. In itself, I don't mind the system of draw magic
date: cast it later". It's everything attached to the system I don't like.\n\n-The leveling system: FF8 is the only FF game to implement enemies with levels themselves. Your characters can level up as you adventure -- that's just standard for an RPG -- but unique to FF8
recommended: the enemies you encounter have their levels set to roughly match yours. Long story short
hoursPlayed: this means that leveling up is actually detrimental
voteText: because the enemies level up too. Oblivion is another game that does this (and it's one of the few flaws with an otherwise dang-near-perfect game)
helpfulPercent: which causes players to just never level up because doing so would be stupid. Leveling up is a key component of any FF game
votesHelpful: but it's butchered in FF8.\n\n-The junction system: Good God
votesTotal: talk about complex character customization. I won't go into all the details
votesFunny: but this is one of the main reasons I just can't enjoy this game. You can boost a character's stats by "junctioning" magic to that stat. This boosts it by a value that's unique per spell
commentsCount: per stat
column16: multiplied by the number of casts you have of that magic. You can stock up to 100 of each spell. Here's where my big problem comes in; you stock this magic up by "drawing" it from enemies. It's a combat action on its own that does nothing to the enemy
column17: and gives you an average of 5.5 casts of the spell you drew. That means when you find a new spell to draw
column18: you need to draw about 18 times to get a full stock of 100. PER CHARACTER. Of which there are six. I probably spent over an hour just drawing up a full stock of about six different spells for about four different characters. Just...no. That's just ridiculous. To the PC version's credit
column19: it comes with a "magic booster" that lets you get a full stock of a whole bunch of spells for all characters any time you want
column20: but that feels like cheating. It's giving you a bunch of spells much earlier than you could otherwise access them. I just can't feel right by cheating in such a way.\n\nThere are several different ways they could have made this system suck less. Capping at 10 instead of 100
column21: for example. That still doesn't change the fact that the junction system as a whole is easily the most convoluted RPG system that exists.\n\n-Lack of character identity: FF7 had this issue too; your characters' combat abilities are defined primarily by the way you've set up their junction system (or materia in 7). You can set up Squall as a bruiser and Rinoa as a mage
column22: then swap their junction setups and have them both perform the other role just fine. This limits the personality that the characters show -- and the issue is only compounded by the immense amount of time you'll spend in combat just spamming draw. This sounds nitpicky
column23: but other FFs reinforce their characters through their combat options. In FF6
column24: Edgar felt like the machinist because he was the only one that could use an autocrossbow. Sabin felt like the brawler because he was the only one that could suplex a freaking train. Shadow felt like the ninja because he was the only one that could hurl a shuriken. All those varying combat options reinforced their character.\n\n-Renzokuken: My last little nitpick that makes the game an absolute joke. Squall's limit break lets him smack an enemy upwards of five times
column26: and the only requirement to use it is to be low on HP. Theoretically
column27: you could make mincemeat out of the entire game just by keeping Squall's HP low and spamming his limit break on anything that moves. Honestly
column29: what was wrong with FF7's limit break system? That worked just fine
column30: and would have easily suited Squall's insane limit break.\n\nSo yeah. I really
column31: really wanted to like this game. I gave it several chances. I just...can't. On the other hand
column33: go grab that! And/Or the remake coming soon!"

reviewText:
Advantages:
>Vintage
>Many hours of fun

Disadvantages*:
>Graphics
>Not ported earlier

This is a must for FF8 fans. If you're wondering why you should buy this, just think about those endless hours you spent playing it as a kid, following walkthroughs published on magazines and such.
However, if you have not played Final Fantasy before, I advise you to check a few gameplay videos - you may not like how it goes, although I think this extremely unlikely to happen.

*I personally don't care about these.

reviewText: The greatest game ever made, now available on your personal computer, once again, through Steam. Though the music is subpar to the Playstation original, the Roses and Wine mod fixes that and even gives you orchestral optons, and The Black Mages' version of Don't Be Afraid. Final Fantasy vIII is a game i fell in love with when i was young, and will always come back to, no matter what. Also, features the greatest FF minigame around: Triple Triad. The amount of time i spent playing Triple Triad on the original version was worthy of the price of the game. I hope we get see more Final Fantasy games from the original I-X run, including X-2, on PC. Come on, Square Enix, make me hate you a little less.

reviewText: Game is simply amazing
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
+ Great nostalgic value
+ Vast open world with lots of secrets
+ Plethora of side quests
+ Triple Triad
+ Chocobo World
+ The junction system provides a wide variety of customization
+ A story revolving around captivating characters
+ Great soundtrack
+ Great designs

- Re-release of the first PC port of the game
- Last decade's controller support didn't transition well into this decade
- Low quality audio files
- Graphic enhancements are hard to notice (if there really are any)
- No wide screen support (instead, it stretches the screen)
- Drawing magic
- The game often unjunctions characters other than Squall and there's no preset options
- World feels generic
- Lore and events are confusing
- requires A LOT of modding

Verdict: FFVIII was a great game back then and the one that introduced me to the franchise, no less. It holds a huge sentimental value to me and I bet to many others. It can still be enjoyable for newer generations, but the gameplay didn't transition well into this decade and Square Enix didn't care to enhance the game properly. For those unaware, this is a re-release of the 2000 port of the original released for the PlayStation. It doesn't improve much, if at all, over the first port and it can be a huge let down for people used to the PS2 gameplay mechanics onwards. For those familiar with the storytelling of FFX and above, VIII might also feel lacking in that department as the world feels very shallow with little history. None of this, however, means is not worth it. The player, epsecially if new, just has to dive into with an open mind and understand that yes, it's a very dated game. Modding the game (check the guides for a list of mods) can help with the experience and bring a twist to the nostalgia seekers.

A note on the DRM: Is not REALLY a DRM. Steam DOES NOT require your to have a Square Enix account to save your progress and register achievement progress. The Square Enix account is optional and the lack of it won't get in the way of your game progress. The problem with this is that the launcher is constantly reminding the player to login, but you don't HAVE to. If you already have a Square Enix account linked to your Steam account, you won't even notice this, not in VIII, not in other Square Enix games that make use of their social network.

reviewText:
It's Final Fantasy 8, on PC, what's there to know?

Well... for starters, the music is an assortment of horrendous midi files, by default. Thankfully the game is easily modded to insert the original PS soundtrack.

On the positive side of things, the game has built in 'cheats' if you're not one for grinding and acquiring spells and such yourself. I didn't use those, but I took full advantage of the Fast-Forward button, making it easy to exploit the card game for early weapons, draw magic from monsters, and skip quickly through scenes I've watched a half dozen times in the past. Oh, and the Pocketstation content, Chocobo World, is built-in, so you can get the few items that were unavailable in the North American console version.

If you haven't played FF8, but are a fan of JRPGs, or enjoyed the game in the past and are iffy on replaying it, I'd strongly recommend it. Works well with the Dualshock 4, grinding is an afterthought, and after you fix the god-awful music, it'll be just as it felt on the PS1.

Easily a 10/10 game. Deserves more credit than it gets.

reviewText:
I honestly love and hate Final Fantasy VIII at the same time.  I love the Draw ability but I hate that you’re punished with lower stats for using magic you’ve Drawn and Junctioned.  (Maybe percentages would have been better?)  I love upgrading weapons instead of buying/finding new ones but hate the lack of armor and the fact that monsters level with you.  I love refining magic and items from other items and making lower magics combine into bigger items, but turning monsters into cards to turn into items was somewhat tedious.  I love the music and the character designs, but by GOD I want to slap each and every one of them.
The plot runs all over the place and reminds me of those assignments in writing class where you write a paragraph and pass it to your left.  You’re mercenaries, you’re assassinating a political figure, you’re a soldier in the past, you’re dealing with the moon and time travel...  perhaps a better translation would help.  It just feels disjointed and thrown together.
As an older teen/young adult I felt Squall was a whiney, unsympathetic character.  Quistis was manipulative, Selphie cute and cliche yet harmless, Zell had SOME character development, and Irvine?  Screw him.  If you KNOW you’re going to freeze on a mission to save your home you better ask someone else to go!  And sharp shooters do NOT work alone, I hate that trope.  I didn’t like Rinoa but I didn’t hate her.  As an adult I thought I’d play the game again, and I understand Squall better, but I pity him now; poor kid’s got PTSD.
Would I recommend this game?  Sadly, no.  It’s just too tedious for me to play though so much I can’t stand to get to the parts I do like.  I’m not going to tell anyone not to play it, though.  Lots of people love this game for legitimate reasons, and more power to them.  It’s not a horrible game, just one I didn’t like.

reviewText:
Playing Final Fantasy VIII a decade and a half later reminded me how to cringe again.

The story starts out with a pointedly anime premise--teenagers at school falling in and out of drama. Squall, who I promptly renamed, has the emotional capacity of a rock for the entire first disc. However, he actually develops as a character later in the game; including a funny moment when Rinoa (renamed Rhino) carefully explains that he needs to convey his thoughts aloud or the others won't understand him. That said, many of the side characters are forgettable, including Zell, who enjoys hot dogs and punching things. The game's love story almost works, but Squall spends most of his time oblivious to Rhino's desperate attempts to be noticed. Very cringeworthy. Around disc 4, the game takes a hit of acid and drops us into time compression, which kind of looks like a Salvadore Dali painting. Entertaining, but batshit crazy.

I go back and forth on the gameplay. Triple Triad is excellent, but its distribution of rules around the world is crippling. Junctioning scratches my itch of watching numbers get higher, but the way information is visually presented is rough at best, and I found myself wishing for a more modern UI. The world map is huge, but largely void of content--especially compared to FFIX, which is full of glorious treasures. Guardian Forces are fun to hunt down for their unlockable abiliies, but the summons themselves don't do nearly as much damage as a normal attack, and they're unskippable. Yep. Maybe there's a mod for that.

The music is excellent as always (thanks Uematsu), however the game defaults to ear-splitting midi unless you make a point of downloading the original tracks like I did. The 1999 graphics obviously aren't great, although many of the full motion videos are still quite entertaining, especially when you're able to control a 3-D character in many of the ridiculous battle scenes, such as when the enormous floating garden" schools collide.

Do I recommend this game? No

reviewText:
It's Final Fantasy VIII.

It's dumb and mechanically broken, but, like me, you love it and want to buy it anyway.

You probably shouldn't.

Regrettably the emulation of a decade plus old game that is not sold commercially is packaged with incredibly intrusive DRM which prevents one from playing without a stable internet connections, and prevents one from even attempting to play whenever Square is experiencing server issues, such as, for example, right now.

The game was purchased but cannot be played until Square sort out their end. A brief foray into the community hub makes it clear that this is not an isolated incident, and is rather something that keeps. on. happening.

Unlike most of the internet, I don't have a problem with DRM. I'm not convinced it works, but it's not my money being lost to piracy, so if a company feels differently and wants to attack pirates this way then more power to them. However, when your DRM renders legitimate, paying customers physically unable to play your game then you've crossed the line into immoral practice.

I have bought, and will now return, a game which cannot be played. It is not because of my computer or errors on my end, and it is not a problem unique to me. This is a widespread, known and recurring issue that Square have actively imposed upon their game.

reviewText:
Note: My recommendation (or lack thereof) is based on the game itself. If you liked FFVIII and just wanted a port of it, then I can say I haven't had any issues with how it runs...although there was some stuttering in the ending cutscene.

I really couldn't get into this game. I couldn't stand the characters from the get go, and on top of that the battle system is tedious as hell. Not only is there level grinding, but you have to actually manage your magic/stats inbetween characters on a very frequent basis. Repeatedly drawing magic from enemies over and over to make your units more powerful and if you actually use the magic you have pooled your characters become weaker again. It actively discourages the usage of magic which is so obnoxious. Everyone is also incredibly varied in terms of what stats you can assign magic to, so that's another thing that adds to the frustration. Overall I just felt like the battle system was too restrictive and unnecessarily complex. I don't mind if things are complicated if they can lead to battles where you really had to think, but honestly you just had to junction magic correctly and then just spam normal attacks, limit breaks, or summons. There's little to no variety required when fighting. To give you an example of how unvaried it is, I fought through every boss and enemy in the game solely by using summons over and over again until I got to the final boss...then I just spammed Zell's limit break to kill it. It was incredibly boring.

On the note of the game being boring, my 160 or so hours of playtime for this game is a gross exaggeration. The reason it's there is because of how many times I'd fallen asleep trying to force myself to finish it.

reviewText:
I am basing this review on both port & game quality.

First, the port is very poorly made, there is no real attention to detail. Some examples include:

* The game minimizes itself when it starts and you have to re-focus the window.

* The game blocks you from using a gamepad right away and requires you to press a key in the beginning to proceed, bad UX.

* The battle transitions look terrible compared to the PS1 version.

* The game uses midi files for music when it is easily modded to play high quality OGG music. They were just lazy with this and it really takes a toll on the game's atmosphere if you don't use a mod for it.

* There is a constant distracting message achievements synchronized with server" every time you draw magic from enemies
date: just because there's an achievement for it
recommended: but you can't turn this message off.\n\n* When you have to do button prompts (there's a few quicktime events)
hoursPlayed: the gamepad buttons appear as B1/B2/B3/B4 rather than icons
voteText: which can get confusing visually
helpfulPercent: if the event requires swift response.\n\n* After you finish the game
votesHelpful: you get a black screen
votesTotal: the devs made no effort to reset the game data and return you back to title screen
votesFunny:
you have to manually exit the game via Alt+F4. It shows that they were not willing to do changes for better UX on the target platform.


Now for the game itself

However it is now entirely possible to just spam GF (The game's Summons) and win every battle as there's no need for MP for them either. This change was unnecessary and breaks the balance/strategy with resource (MP/Item Stock) management as the player feels like he has infinite amount of resources for a battle

When the game first came out

column83: cannot recommend this port to anyone looking to either start with Final Fantasy or looking to play the next classic Final Fantasy.\nGet this game only if you want it on your collection or for nostalgia reasons
